European Stocks Rise as Trading Sentiment Lifted by US -Canada Trade Entente
European Stocks Rise as Trading Sentiment Lifted by US-Canada Trade 
Entente
MT Newswires Live Briefs PRO
October 1, 2018 Monday 7:43 AM EST
Copyright 2018 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 282 words
Body
 European equity benchmarks were advancing on Monday, with trading sentiment was lifted by news that the US 
and Canada had reached an agreement on trade which will replace the former North American Free Trade 
Agreement after more than a year of negotiations.
The new deal, which is known as the United States - Mexico - Canada Agreement, aims to result in freer markets 
and robust economic growth, according to a joint statement issued by Robert Lighthizer, the US trade 
representative and Chrystia Freeland, Canada's foreign affairs minister.
In other economic news, Germany posted its latest data on retail turnover, which showed a 1.6% jump year on year 
and a 0.1% decline from the previous month in real terms, according to Destatis, Germany's federal statistics office. 
In equities, low-cost airline Ryanair was leading the decliners on the pan-European Stoxx 600 Index, down by 9.3% 
after it issued a profit warning early Monday, blaming coordinated industrial action and higher oil prices for its 
revised profit outlook for the fiscal year. Rival airlines easyJet and Air France KLM were 2.5% and 3.0% lower on 
the index, respectively. Finnish industrial machinery company Metso, and Trelleborg AB Series B, an engineering 
group, were 3.0% and 2.7% lower, respectively. 
Gainers on the pan-European Stoxx 600 Index were led by chemical company Linde, 6.0% higher, followed by 
medical devices manufacturer Ambu A/S Series B, up by 4.3% and Zalando, 4.4% higher.
The pan-European Stoxx 600 Index was 0.27% higher, London's FTSE 100 Index was up by 0.09%, Frankfurt's 
DAX was 0.55% higher and Paris' CAC-40 was up by 0.27% at the time of writing. 
Price: 28.49, Change: -0.41, Percent Change: -1.42
Load-Date: October 2, 2018
European Stocks Rise as Trading Sentiment Lifted by US -Canada Trade Entente
End of Document
Street Color: S&P NAFTA-Induced Rally 'Excessive,' JPMorgan Says
Street Color: S&P NAFTA-Induced Rally 'Excessive,' JPMorgan Says
MT Newswires Live Briefs
October 1, 2018 Monday 7:24 AM EST
Copyright 2018 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 351 words
Body
 The rally in the S&P Monday morning on the back of the US-Canadian trade agreement seems a bit excessive as 
the fate of NAFTA was not as large a market overhang as it appeared, JPMorgan said. Congress was never going 
to approve a Canada-less NAFTA and President Trump didn't have the clear authority to withdraw from the existing 
agreement.
The US-China outlook, meanwhile, continues to deteriorate as trade disputes bleed out to other realms of the 
relationship, the bank said. JPMorgan's economists on Friday changed their US-China assumptions and were now 
modeling a 25% tariff imposed on all Chinese imports starting in 2019.
Economic data released Monday morning was generally underwhelming: manufacturing PMIs came in below 
forecast in China, Japan and Europe while German retail sales, Macau gaming revenues and South Korean exports 
also fell short.
Trading in Asia was very quiet as Hong Kong and mainland China were closed. TPX rose 0.04%, NKY rose 0.52%, 
Taiwan rose 0.41%, South Korea fell 0.18%, Australia fell 0.57% and India closed about 20 points higher.  
The major Eurozone indices were trading higher thanks to the US-NAFTA news; outperformers included autos, 
basic resources, chemicals, tech and energy while staples, banks, real estate and healthcare lagged. The Italian 
FTSEMIB rebounded 1% after falling Friday on the budget news. Investors await comments out of the EU on Italy's 
budget proposal as Italian finance officials gather in Luxembourg this morning. 
Linde shares were among the top performers in the Eurostoxx after China approved the PX deal (over the 
weekend) while Ryanair led to the downside following a negative profit update. The dollar index was unchanged, 
while the loonie rallied about 80 points on the NAFTA news. Tesla shares were rallying 15% pre-open following the 
Musk and SEC settlement.
Street Color: S&P NAFTA-Induced Rally 'Excessive,' JPMorgan Says
(Street Color news is derived from real time chats with market professionals subscribed to the Ask Alyce Premium 
Chat service on Bloomberg and ICE IM. This information is believed to be from reliable sources but may include 
rumor and speculation. Accuracy is not guaranteed.)
Load-Date: October 2, 2018
End of Document
European ADRs Move Higher in Monday Trading
European ADRs Move Higher in Monday Trading
MT Newswires Live Briefs
October 1, 2018 Monday 10:44 AM EST
Copyright 2018 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 231 words
Body
 American depositary receipts of European stocks were trading 0.44% higher at 136.07 on the Bank of New York 
Mellon Europe ADR Index on Monday.
In continental Europe, the gainers were led by biotech firm MorphoSys (MOR), and kidney dialysis company 
Fresenius Medical Care (FMS), which rose 3.8% and 2.7% respectively. They were followed by ASML (ASML), a 
manufacturer of chip-making equipment, and bank Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria (BBVA), which were up 1.8% 
and 1.4%.
The decliners in continental Europe were led by marketing firm Criteo (CRTO), and telecommunications operator 
Telecom Italia (TI), which fell 2.8% and 3.8% respectively. They were followed by software firm Talend (TLND), and 
brewing company AB InBev (BUD), which were off 1.9% and 0.9%.
In the UK and Ireland, the gainers were led biotech company Midatech Pharma (MTP), and biopharmaceutical 
company Amarin (AMRN) which surged 12.5% and 10.7% respectively. They were followed by biopharmaceutical 
firms Motif Bio (MTFB) and Akari Therapeutics (AKTX), which climbed 10.3% and 1.6%. 
The decliners in the UK and Ireland were led by airline operator Ryanair (RYAAY), which tumbled 15.3%, followed 
by gene therapy company Nightstar (NITE), biopharmaceutical company GW Pharmaceuticals (GWPH), and 
biotech firm Shire (SHPG), and which fell 3.6%, 1.6%, and 1.8% respectively.
Price: 0.65, Change: +0.07, Percent Change: +12.48
Load-Date: October 2, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair Blames Strikes, Higher Oil Prices for Slashing of Full-Year Profit Outlook
Ryanair Blames Strikes, Higher Oil Prices for Slashing of Full-Year Profit 
Outlook
MT Newswires Live Briefs PRO
October 1, 2018 Monday 6:42 AM EST
Copyright 2018 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 312 words
Body
 Europe's biggest budget airline Ryanair (RYAAY, RYA.L) issued a profit warning early Monday, blaming 
coordinated industrial action and higher oil prices for its revised profit outlook for the fiscal year.
The carrier said in a trading statement that pre-tax profit in fiscal 2019 is now expected to come in a new range of 
1.10 -1.20 billion euros ($1.28-1.39 billion) compared with a previous estimate of 1.25-1.35 billion euros.   
In September, Ryanair reported two coordinated strikes in Germany, Holland, Belgium, Spain, and Portugal, which 
it claimed occurred despite the airline agreeing to meet union demands for local contracts, local law, and a five-
week arbitration with pilots in Germany when the VC Union sought a prolonged five-month arbitration.
It said that second-quarter fares were down about 3% - versus a previous forecast of an increase of 1% - because 
of the weakness caused to close-in bookings and fares, which it said were mainly the result of the two five-nation 
strikes. 
"We had until last week expected stronger third-quarter fares to recover softer second-quarter yields but over the 
past week third-quarter fares, and customer confidence, have been affected by worries about possible strikes," the 
company said in the statement. "We are now guiding second-half fares down 2% (previously flat)."
Ryanair noted that the strikes also added to its flight-compensation EU261 costs while, concurrently, it said that the 
unhedged fuel costs have also jumped as oil prices increased to $82 per barrel. It warned that the fuel bill would be 
about 460 million euros higher - versus a previous guidance of 430 million euros - from a year ago.
In response to the lower fare, higher oil prices, and the elevated EU261 cost environment, the budget airline said it 
has decided to trim its winter 2018 capacity by 1%. 
Price: 96.04, Change: -1.23, Percent Change: -1.26
Ryanair Blames Strikes, Higher Oil Prices for Slashing of Full-Year Profit Outlook
Load-Date: October 2, 2018
End of Document
TN Equities Jump on North America Trade Pact as Dow Rallies Third Day, S&P Nears Record
TN Equities Jump on North America Trade Pact as Dow Rallies Third Day, 
S&P Nears Record
MT Newswires Live Briefs
October 1, 2018 Monday 4:14 PM EST
Copyright 2018 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 321 words
Body
 Stocks in the US were mostly in the green on the Monday, as the Dow Jones Industrial Average led the gains as 
investors cheered a new trade deal between the world's biggest economy and its neighbors, Canada and Mexico. 
The blue-chip measure rose for a third straight day, coming within less than 100 points of the record high it reached 
last month as trade-sensitive names advanced. Boeing (BA) rose 2.9% and Chevron (CVX) advanced 1.8% as oil 
prices surged. 
The jump in crude futures led the Standard & Poor's 500 energy sector to the best rise among the groups, ending 
1.5% in the green by the bell. ConocoPhillips (COP) gained 3.2% after saying it agreed to sell to the government of 
Timor-Leste in southeast Asia its 30% interest in the Greater Sunrise Fields. 
On the downside, the Nasdaq Composite gave back its earlier advance as Intel (INTC) weighed after downbeat 
analyst comments. The chipmaker fell 1.8%. American Airlines (AAL) dropped 4.2% on a negative day for airline 
stocks after a profit warning from Irish carrier Ryanair (RYAAY), which plunged 15%. Delta Air Lines (DAL) fell 2.1% 
and JetBlue (JBLU) decreased 1.9%. 
But the tone on the day was generally upbeat after the US, Mexico and Canada trade deal reached late Sunday 
night set in motion a buying spree that included gains in the auto and materials sector. General Motors (GM) rose 
1.6% and Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) climbed 2.7% after a new management team was named for the carmaker.
The trade news helped overshadow some downbeat economic data that included a below-consensus 0.1% 
increase in construction spending for August, and a slight decline in the ISM manufacturing index to 59.8 in 
September from 61.3 in August, missing the 59.9 estimates. IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde also offered 
a warned about a "less bright" outlook for global economic growth. 
By the close, the Dow rose 0.7%, the S&P 500 gained 0.4% and the Nasdaq was down by 0.1%. 
TN Equities Jump on North America Trade Pact as Dow Rallies Third Day, S&P Nears Record
Load-Date: October 2, 2018
End of Document

LONDON MARKET OPEN: Turbulence For easyJet , IAG After Ryanair Warning
LONDON MARKET OPEN: Turbulence For easyJet, IAG After Ryanair 
Warning
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
October 1, 2018 Monday 3:46 AM EST
Copyright 2018 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 761 words
Body
 London stocks were mixed early Monday, with a profit warning from Ryanair leading to bumpy trade for FTSE 100-
listed airline stocks easyJet and International Consolidated Airlines.
In focus in the UK on Monday is September's manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index, which is expected to 
decline slightly from August.
The FTSE 100 was down 0.1%, or 8.30 points, at 7,501.90. The FTSE 250 was up 0.3%, or 51.86 points, at 
20,358.90 while the AIM All-Share was up 0.1% at 1,099.55.
The Cboe UK 100 was down 0.3% at 12,723.19. The Cboe UK 250 was up 0.1% at 18,456.53 and the Cboe UK 
Small Companies down 0.1% at 12,133.50.
Over in mainland Europe, the CAC 40 in Paris and DAX 30 in Frankfurt were up 0.1% and 0.3% higher respectively. 
Sinking 7.7% in early trade was Ryanair after cutting its annual profit guidance by 12% due to higher oil prices and 
strikes.
Profit guidance for its current financial year ending March 31, 2019, was lowered to a range of EUR1.10 billion to 
EUR1.20 billion, from EUR1.25 billion to EUR1.35 billion seen previously, as a result of lower traffic and weaker 
fares in September, caused by two years of coordinated strikes across Europe.
Fares for the second half of the year are guided to be down 2%, from its previous expectation of remaining flat from 
the year before, and slower traffic growth is expected to cut traffic for the full year to 138 million, from the previous 
guidance of 139 million.
The budget Irish airline added that it cannot rule out further disruptions in the third quarter ending December, which 
could see its profit guidance lowered even more.
LONDON MARKET OPEN: Turbulence For easyJet , IAG After Ryanair Warning
The update from Ryanair hit easyJet in a negative read-across, down 4.5% and the FTSE 100's worst performer 
early Monday, while British Airways parent International Consolidated Airlines was down 2.5%.
Towards the other end of the index, United Utilities gained 1.3% after Deutsche Bank raised the water firm to Buy 
from Hold.
RSA Insurance was also benefiting from a broker rating upgrade, 1.3% higher after Berenberg raised the stock to 
Buy from Hold.
Just Group was at the bottom of the mid-caps, down 7.6% after announcing its chief financial officer of 12 years will 
be stepping down. 
Simon Thomas is to step down as chief financial officer at the end of October. David Richardson, currently deputy 
chief executive officer and managing director of UK corporate business, be appointed interim CFO in addition to his 
current responsibilities. The search for a permanent replacement for Thomas is now underway, Just Group said.
The economic calendar on Monday has manufacturing PMIs from France, Germany, the eurozone and the UK at 
0850 BST, 0855 BST, 0900 BST and 0930 BST respectively. In the US, the Markit manufacturing PMI is at 1445 
BST while the ISM manufacturing PMI is at 1500 BST.
Sterling was quoted at USD1.3039 early Monday ahead of the manufacturing data, soft compared to USD1.3048 at 
the London equities close on Friday.
The UK manufacturing reading is seen declining slightly to 52.5 in September from the 52.8 posted for last month.
Already released, manufacturing data from China overnight showed the country's manufacturing sector weakened 
in September amidst an ongoing trade war with the US.
The official manufacturing purchasing managers index stood at 50.8 in September, a drop from August's 51.3, 
according to data from the National Bureau of Statistics, and below consensus of 51.2.
The independent Caixin manufacturing PMI fell from 50.6 in August to 50, the lowest level in more than one year. 
Any score above 50 indicates expansion in the sector, while a reading below the mark indicates contraction.
In Asia on Monday, the Japanese Nikkei 225 index closed up 0.5%. Markets in China are closed this week for the 
National Day holiday, though Hong Kong will re-open on Tuesday.
Back in the UK, the Conservative Party conference kicked off on Sunday amid intense debate over Prime Minister 
Theresa May's "Chequers" strategy.
The four-day event, taking place in Birmingham, comes with speculation that eurosceptics could challenge May's 
leadership in order to steer Britain towards a Canada-style free-trade deal after Brexit.
In an interview published in the Sunday Times just hours before the conference kicked off, former foreign secretary 
Boris Johnson described May's plan for leaving the EU as "deranged" and "preposterous."
Johnson will be speaking at a conference fringe event on Tuesday, while May delivers a closing speech on 
Wednesday. In the address, she is expected to urge the party to rally behind her Brexit deal as well as focusing on 
immigration.
Load-Date: October 2, 2018
End of Document
LONDON MARKET CLOSE: Royal Mail And Ryanair Profit Warnings Sink FTSE
LONDON MARKET CLOSE: Royal Mail And Ryanair Profit Warnings Sink 
FTSE
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
October 1, 2018 Monday 12:10 PM EST
Copyright 2018 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 1473 words
Body
 Stocks in London ended mixed on Monday, as sharp falls from Royal Mail, airlines and housebuilders stocks saw 
the FTSE 100 slip below the 7,500 mark.
The FTSE 100 index closed down 0.2%, or 14.53 points at 7,495.67. The FTSE 250 ended up 0.5%, or 94.17 
points, at 20,401.21, and the AIM All-Share closed up 0.3%, or 3.11 points, at 1,101.61.
The Cboe UK 100 ended down 0.3% at 12,727.98, the Cboe 250 closed up 0.4% at 18,514.60, and the Cboe Small 
Companies ended 0.1% lower at 12,135.16.
On the London Stock Exchange, Rentokil Initial ended up 3.6% as the pest control firm acquired outsourcer Mitie 
Group's pest control unit for GBP40 million in cash.
RSA Insurance closed up 2.8% after Berenberg raised the insurer to Buy from Hold, believing there was an "over-
reaction" to last week's weather-battered trading update.
Languishing at the other end of the large cap index, Royal Mail ended the the worst performer down 18% after the 
postal operator forecast lower full-year profit amid challenging conditions in the UK. 
Royal Mail revised its adjusted operating profit before transformation costs down to between GBP500 million and 
GBP550 million for its full financial year ending March. This compares to a GBP694 million adjusted operating profit 
the year before.
Royal Mail's UK productivity performance was "significantly below plan" at just 0.1% in the first half of its financial 
year with full year performance expected to be "significantly below target" at the upper end of the 2% to 3% range.
As such, cost savings targets have subsequently been dropped to GBP100 million from GBP230 million with plans 
to implement "a range of short-term cost actions" being enacted.
LONDON MARKET CLOSE: Royal Mail And Ryanair Profit Warnings Sink FTSE
"This is a cause for concern for many investors despite the fact that management have stated that the attractive 
dividend will be unaffected. We would hope that the parcels and GLS business can continue with their rapid growth. 
A stalling here, caused by perhaps industrial action or competitive pressures, will surely result in further troubles for 
the group," said Share Centre analyst Helal Miah.
Blue chip airlines were also reeling in the wake of a profit warning from Irish carrier Ryanair Holdings, which cut its 
forecast for full-year profit, citing rising oil prices and the impact of recent coordinated strikes across Europe.
Ryanair shares closed down 13% while peers easyJet and British Airways parent International Consolidated 
Airlines Group ended down 7.0% and 2.6% respectively. 
Ryanair's profit guidance for the year to the end of March 31, 2019, was lowered to a range of EUR1.10 billion to 
EUR1.20 billion, from EUR1.25 billion to EUR1.35 billion. For 2018 financial year, pretax profit increased 10% year-
on-year to EUR1.61 billion from EUR1.47 billion in 2017 financial year. 
The Irish budget airline also attributed the cut in profit guidance to increased care and re-acommodation expenses 
as a result of strikes and fall in forward bookings. 
In addition, Ryanair said it could not rule out further disruptions in the third quarter ending December, which could 
see its profit guidance lowered even more.
In addition, housebuilders also ended among the worst blue chip performers after UK Prime Minister Theresa May 
over the weekend announced plans for a stamp duty surcharge of between 1% and 3% to be imposed on sales of 
property to foreign nationals who do not pay UK tax. 
Berkeley Group closed down 3.4%, Persimmon down 1.9%, Barratt Developments down 1.6%, Taylor Wimpey 
down 2.0%. 
The capital raised would go towards measures to tackle rough sleeping, and is designed to ease pressure on the 
housing market and make homes more affordable. 
Analysts at Shore Capital called the idea "ill-judged" and a move that plays on the idea that overseas house buyers 
leave the properties empty.
The pound was quoted at USD1.3040 at the London equities close, compared to USD1.3048 at the close on Friday, 
despite data showing that UK manufacturing sector activity saw an unexpected upturn in the month of September.
The UK manufacturing sector expanded at a faster pace in September, survey data from IHS Markit and Chartered 
Institute of Procurement & Supply showed. 
The manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index rose to 53.8 in September from 53.0 in August, which was revised 
up from 52.8. Any reading above 50 indicates expansion in the sector.
"The reaction in the forex market has been very much mute as the bigger focus remains on the Brexit related 
issues. But the silver lining is that the manufacturing data is still above the critical level of 50 which shows 
expansion but the net lending numbers are dropping and this shows that credit conditions are not becoming better 
in the country," said ThinkMarkets analyst Naeem Aslam.
As the Conservative Party conference rolled on in Birmingham, UK Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond 
used his keynote speech as a rallying cry to urge fellow party members to "stand together" as Prime Minister 
Theresa May seeks to secure a Brexit deal based on her Chequers plan.
The chancellor promised he would maintain "enough fiscal firepower" to support the economy in the case of a no-
deal Brexit.
LONDON MARKET CLOSE: Royal Mail And Ryanair Profit Warnings Sink FTSE
Declaring that the Conservatives remained "the party of business", Hammond announced reforms of the 
apprenticeship levy to meet companies' concerns as well as a GBP125 million package to boost the number of well-
paid jobs across the UK.
Hammond could not resist making a few jibes at the Labour party's expense as he denounced the opposition as a 
"backward-looking party" which is "totally unfit to govern", he said.
The Runnymede and Weybridge MP won applause from activists as he declared: "Jeremy Corbyn boasts that 
Labour are a government-in-waiting. Well, I say let's keep him waiting, this year, next year and every year".
In Paris the CAC 40 ended up 0.2%, while the DAX 30 in Frankfurt ended up 0.8%. 
The euro stood at USD1.1566 at the European equities close, against USD1.1619 late Friday, despite the jobless 
rate in the eurozone falling to its lowest level in a decade. 
Unemployment in the eurozone dropped to 8.1% in August, the lowest rate since November 2008, according to 
data from the EU's statistics agency Eurostat.
Across the 19-country currency bloc, 13.2 million people were without a job in August, according to the figures from 
Eurostat. The figure represents a fall of 0.1 percentage point from July.
Stocks in New York were higher at the London equities close amid optimism over US and Canadian officials 
agreeing a trade deal to replace the North American Free Trade Agreement shortly before a midnight deadline.
The DJIA was up 1%, the S&P 500 index up 0.7% and the Nasdaq Composite up 0.5%.
The new trade deal, called the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement, or USMCA, will reportedly provide more market 
access to US dairy farmers and effectively cap Canadian automobile exports to the US.
In a joint statement US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Canadian Foreign Affairs Minister Chrystia 
Freeland said the agreement will "strengthen the middle class, and create good, well-paying jobs and new 
opportunities for the nearly half billion people who call North America home".
US President Donald Trump, a harsh critic of NAFTA, praised the USMCA as a "historic transaction" in a post on 
Twitter on Monday.
The leaders of the US, Canada, and Mexico are expected to sign the new agreement before the end of November, 
although it will still need to be approved by Congress.
Elsewhere, US Federal Chair Jerome Powell will speak at the National Association for Business Economics' annual 
meeting on Tuesday at 1745 BST. 
Brent oil was higher quoted at USD84.70 a barrel at the London equities close from USD82.85 at the close Friday, 
its highest level since November 2014. 
Investors widely expect the North Sea benchmark to hit USD100 per barrel for the first time since 2015's crash 
amid rising geopolitical risks, including looming US sanctions on Iran, which will come into effect on November 4.
The sanctions would squeeze Iranian crude exports, hitting the market despite other exporters increasing supply.
Oil prices also remain supported by supply disruptions in places such as Venezuela and the recent decision of the 
Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and its allies to leave production steady.
Gold was quoted at USD1,188.75 an ounce at the London equities close against USD1,192.70 late Friday.
LONDON MARKET CLOSE: Royal Mail And Ryanair Profit Warnings Sink FTSE
The economic events calendar on Tuesday has UK Nationwide house price index and construction PMI data at 
0700 BST and 0930 BST respectively. There are also eurozone producer prices at 1000 BST. Stock markets in 
China are closed for the National Day Golden Week holiday. 
The UK corporate calendar on Tuesday has full year results from plumbing and heating products supplier Ferguson, 
bar and restaurant operator Revolution Bars and from furniture and floorings retailer ScS Group.

European Shares Rebound As US, Canada Reach Deal To Save NAFTA
European Shares Rebound As US, Canada Reach Deal To Save NAFTA
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
October 1, 2018 Monday 6:46 AM EST
Copyright 2018 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 379 words
Body
 European stocks rebounded on Monday amid easing trade concerns after the US and Canada reached an 
agreement on a framework North American Free Trade Agreement deal.
The pan-European Stoxx Europe 600 index was up 0.36% at 384.57 in late opening deals after declining 0.8% on 
Friday.
The German DAX was rising 0.7%, France's CAC 40 index was moving up 0.3% and the UK's FTSE 100 was 
marginally higher.
Swiss bakery business Aryzta soared as much as 32%. The company forecast stable underlying results in FY2019 
after narrowing its fiscal 2018 loss.
ThyssenKrupp rose half a percent in Frankfurt after its supervisory board unanimously approved a plan to divide the 
group into two separate companies.
Linde AG advanced 1.3%. The company has received approval for its proposed USD83 billion merger with Praxair 
PX.N from the Chinese antitrust authority.
French supermarket group Casino gained 0.8% after it agreed to sell some property assets for 565 million euros to 
reduce debt levels.
Ryanair slumped almost 9% in London. The airline cut its forecast for full-year profit, citing rising oil prices and the 
impact of recent coordinated strikes across Europe.
Peer Easyjet tumbled 3.3%, BA owner IAG dropped 1.5% and Air-France KLM lost 2.5%.
In economic releases, Eurozone manufacturing activity grew at the weakest pace in two years in September, final 
data from IHS Markit showed. The factory Purchasing Managers' Index fell to 53.2, the lowest since September 
2016, from 54.6 in August. The initial estimate was 53.3.
European Shares Rebound As US, Canada Reach Deal To Save NAFTA
The euro area jobless rate fell to 8.1% in August from 8.2% in July, Eurostat reported. This was the lowest since 
November 2008.
German retail sales grew by real 1.6% year-on-year in August, faster than the 0.9% expansion seen a month ago, 
figures from Destatis showed. The annual rate came in line with expectations.
The UK manufacturing sector expanded at a faster pace in September, survey data from IHS Markit and Chartered 
Institute of Procurement & Supply showed.
The manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index rose to 53.8 in September from 53.0 in August, which was revised 
up from 52.8.
The pound rose after Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond said the EU was in the mood to do a divorce 
deal, but uncertainty over Brexit had already hit the UK's economy.

European Stocks End Mostly Higher Amid Easing Trade Concerns
European Stocks End Mostly Higher Amid Easing Trade Concerns
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
October 1, 2018 Monday 12:08 PM EST
Copyright 2018 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 471 words
Body
 European stocks turned in a strong performance on Monday amid easing trade concerns after the US and Canada 
agreed on a trade deal to replace the North American Free Trade Agreement shortly before a midnight deadline.
The pan-European Stoxx Europe 600 Index rose by 0.3%, while the Euro Stoxx 50 Index of eurozone blue chip 
stocks climbed by 0.5%.
The German DAX Index also advanced by 0.8% and the French CAC 40 Index crept up by 0.2%, while UK's FTSE 
100 Index bucked the uptrend and edged down by 0.2%.
The new trade deal, called the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement, or USMCA, will reportedly provide more market 
access to US dairy farmers and effectively cap Canadian automobile exports to the US
A joint statement by US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Canadian Foreign Affairs Minister Chrystia 
Freeland said the USMCA will "strengthen the middle class, and create good, well-paying jobs and new 
opportunities for the nearly half billion people who call North America home."
"We look forward to further deepening our close economic ties when this new agreement enters into force," 
Lighthizer and Freeland added.
The leaders of the US, Canada, and Mexico are expected to sign the new agreement before the end of November, 
although it will still need to be approved by Congress.
Swiss bakery business Aryzta spiked 16% after the company forecast stable underlying results in fiscal 2019 after 
narrowing its fiscal 2018 loss.
Linde AG also moved higher after the company received approval for its proposed USD83 billion merger with 
Praxair from the Chinese antitrust authority.
On the other hand, Ryanair slumped 13% in London. The airline cut its forecast for full-year profit, citing rising oil 
prices and the impact of recent coordinated strikes across Europe.
European Stocks End Mostly Higher Amid Easing Trade Concerns
In economic news, Eurozone manufacturing activity grew at the weakest pace in two years in September, final data 
from IHS Markit showed. The factory Purchasing Managers' Index fell to 53.2 from 54.6 in August, hitting the lowest 
level since September of 2016. The initial estimate was 53.3.
The euro area jobless rate fell to 8.1% in August from 8.2% in July, Eurostat reported. This was the lowest since 
November of 2008.
German retail sales grew by real 1.6% year-on-year in August, faster than the 0.9% expansion seen a month ago, 
figures from Destatis showed. The annual rate came in line with expectations.
The UK manufacturing sector expanded at a faster pace in September, survey data from IHS Markit and Chartered 
Institute of Procurement & Supply showed.
The manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index rose to 53.8 in September from 53.0 in August, which was 
upwardly revised from 52.8.
The pound rose after Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond said the EU was in the mood to do a divorce 
deal, but uncertainty over Brexit had already hit the UK's economy.

Ryanair lowers full year profit forecast as strikes take toll
Ryanair lowers full year profit forecast as strikes take toll
Business World (Digest)
October 01, 2018 Monday
Copyright 2018 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: GENERAL
Length: 276 words
Byline: Business World
Body
Ryanair cut its forecast for full-year profit by 12% on Monday and said worse may be to come if recent coordinated 
strikes across Europe continue to hit traffic and bookings.
Europe's largest low-cost carrier has faced multiple strikes since it bowed to pressure to recognize trade unions for 
the first time last December and they have escalated in recent months as it makes slow progress in talks with some 
unions .
The Irish airline said it now expects profit for the year, excluding start up losses in Laudamotion, to come in 
between 1.10-1.20 billion euros, compared with its prior forecast of 1.25-1.35 billion euros.
It added that it could not rule out further disruptions in the coming months, which may require full-year forecasts to 
be lowered again and further cuts to its loss-making winter capacity.
Shares in the airline were 8.6% lower at 11.99 euros by 0710 GMT.
Ryanair said fares in its second quarter to end-September had fallen by around 3% compared with its previous 
forecast for a drop of 1 percent and said that it now expects fares in the second half to be 2% lower.
To cope with lower fares, higher oil prices and strike costs, Ryanair has trimmed its winter capacity by 1%, 
removing aircraft from its Eindhoven, Bremen and Niederrhein bases.
"Two recent coordinated strikes by cabin crew and pilots across five EU countries have affected passenger 
numbers, close in bookings and yields, and forward air fares into Q3," Ryanair chief Michael O'Leary said in a 
statement.
Ryanair lowers full year profit forecast as strikes take toll
"Customer confidence, forward bookings and Q3 fares have been affected, most notably over the October school 
mid-terms and Christmas." (Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: October 23, 2018
End of Document
Sirius Aviation Capital targets used narrowbodies
Sirius Aviation Capital targets used narrowbodies
AirFinance Journal
October 2018
Copyright 2018 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 343 words
Byline: Alex Derber
Body
Ex-Ryanair and Stellwagen executives are to launch a new aircraft lessor via a planned initial public offering.
Sirius Aviation Capital plans to raise $250 million on the London stock exchange for Sirius Aircraft Leasing Fund 
(SALF) to invest mainly in used single-aisle aircraft.
“Globally we intend to leverage this capability to access portfolios of in demand single-aisle aircraft (with leases 
attached), principally from lessors disposing of older aircraft in order to maintain the average age of their fleet,” said 
Howard Millar, chief executive officer of Sirius Aviation Capital.
The company believes there is growing demand for used aircraft and a liquid secondary leasing market “with large 
airline operators such as International Airlines Group and Lufthansa active operators of these older aircraft”.
Millar was deputy chief executive at Ryanair until 2014 before a spell as chief executive of aviation financier 
Stellwagen Capital.
Two other ex-Stellwagen executives, Edward Coughlan and Edward Hansom, will serve as Sirius’s chief 
commercial officer and chief investment officer, respectively.
Millar, Coughlan and Hansom resigned from Stellwagen in acrimonious circumstances in late 2017, when 
Stellwagen Group's CEO Douglas Brennan accused them of attempting to divert valuable business away from the 
company.Another former Stellwagen executive, Kieran Ryan, will be Sirius’s chief financial officer.
In addition to Sirius’s IPO, the company is launching a 12-month placing programme for up to a further 300 million 
ordinary shares and/or C shares.
Sirius is targeting an annualised dividend yield of 8% and a long-term IRR of 10% per annum.
Millar says that the funds raised from the IPO should be invested within six months of its completion.
Liberum Capital is acting as sponsor in relation to the share issue, and is working alongside J&E Davy as joint 
financial adviser and joint placing agent.
Further details will be set out in the company's prospectus, which is expected to be published in late October.
Sirius Aviation Capital targets used narrowbodies
Load-Date: February 12, 2019
End of Document
European Stocks Move Mostly Higher Amid Easing Trade Concerns
European Stocks Move Mostly Higher Amid Easing Trade Concerns
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
October 1, 2018 Monday 6:00 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 503 words
Body
       BRUSSELS/FRANKFURT/PARIS (dpa-AFX) - European stocks turned in a strong performance on Monday 
amid easing trade concerns after the U.S. and Canada agreed on a trade deal to replace the North American Free 
Trade Agreement shortly before a midnight deadline.  The pan-European Stoxx Europe 600 Index rose by 0.3 
percent, while the Euro Stoxx 50 Index of eurozone blue chip stocks climbed by 0.5 percent.  The German DAX 
Index also advanced by 0.8 percent and the French CAC 40 Index crept up by 0.2 percent, while U.K.'s FTSE 100 
Index bucked the uptrend and edged down by 0.2 percent. 
 The new trade deal, called the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement, or USMCA, will reportedly provide more 
market access to U.S. dairy farmers and effectively cap Canadian automobile exports to the U.S.  A joint statement 
by U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Canadian Foreign Affairs Minister Chrystia Freeland said the 
USMCA will 'strengthen the middle class, and create good, well-paying jobs and new opportunities for the nearly 
half billion people who call North America home.'   'We look forward to further deepening our close economic ties 
when this new agreement enters into force,' Lighthizer and Freeland added.  The leaders of the U.S., Canada, and 
Mexico are expected to sign the new agreement before the end of November, although it will still need to be 
approved by Congress.  Swiss bakery business Aryzta spiked 16.4 percent after the company forecast stable 
underlying results in fiscal 2019 after narrowing its fiscal 2018 loss.   Linde AG also moved higher after the 
company received approval for its proposed $83 billion merger with Praxair from the Chinese antitrust authority.  On 
the other hand, Ryanair slumped 12.8 in London. The airline cut its forecast for full-year profit, citing rising oil prices 
and the impact of recent coordinated strikes across Europe.  In economic news, Eurozone manufacturing activity 
grew at the weakest pace in two years in September, final data from IHS Markit showed. The factory Purchasing 
Managers' Index fell to 53.2 from 54.6 in August, hitting the lowest level since September of 2016. The initial 
estimate was 53.3.  The euro area jobless rate fell to 8.1 percent in August from 8.2 percent in July, Eurostat 
reported. This was the lowest since November of 2008.  German retail sales grew by real 1.6 percent year-on-year 
in August, faster than the 0.9 percent expansion seen a month ago, figures from Destatis showed. The annual rate 
came in line with expectations.  The U.K. manufacturing sector expanded at a faster pace in September, survey 
data from IHS Markit and Chartered Institute of Procurement & Supply showed.  The manufacturing Purchasing 
Managers' Index rose to 53.8 in September from 53.0 in August, which was upwardly revised from 52.8.  The pound 
European Stocks Move Mostly Higher Amid Easing Trade Concerns
rose after Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond said the European Union was in the mood to do a divorce 
deal, but uncertainty over Brexit had already hit the U.K.'s economy.

Ryanair Cuts FY19 View Due To Recent Strikes; Stock Down
Ryanair Cuts FY19 View Due To Recent Strikes; Stock Down
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
October 1, 2018 Monday 9:09 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 361 words
Body
       LONDON (dpa-AFX) - Ryanair Holdings plc (RYA.L, RYAAY) announced Monday that it has lowered its full 
year profit guidance, excluding Laudamotion, to a new range of 1.10 billion euros to 1.20 billion euros from the 
previously expected range of 1.25 billion euros to 1.35 billion euros.  The company's cut in fiscal 2019 guidance by 
12% is due to higher oil prices, higher EU261 costs, & weaker fares due to recent strikes.  The company reported 
lower traffic and weaker close in fares in September, caused by 2 days of coordinated pilot/cabin crew strikes in 
Germany, Holland, Belgium, Spain and Portugal. 
 Lower Q3 fares also reported as forward bookings, particularly for the Oct school mid-terms and Christmas, and 
customer confidence are affected by fear of further strikes.  Ryanair noted that Q2 & Q3 traffic and fares will be 
somewhat lower than expected largely as a result of these 2 recent -5 country- strikes, which are being incited by 
competitor employees. This is despite the fact that Ryanair has agreed to meet union demands for local contracts, 
local law, and a 5 week arbitration with pilots in Germany when the VC Union sought a prolonged 5 month 
arbitration.  The company is now guiding H2 fares down 2%, compared to previous estimate of flat. Fuel bill will now 
be approximately 460 million euros higher than last year, compared to previous estimate of 430 million euros 
higher.  Further, slower traffic growth in H2 will cut FY19 traffic to 138 million, in comparison to previous estimate of 
139 million excluding Laudamotion.  Ryanair added that it cannot rule out further disruptions in Q3, which may 
require full year guidance to be lowered further and may necessitate further trimming of loss making winter 
capacity.  Ryanair's Michael O'Leary said, 'While we regret these disruptions, we have on both strike days operated 
over 90% of our schedule. However, customer confidence, forward bookings and Q3 fares has been affected, most 
notably over the Oct school mid-terms and Christmas, in those 5 countries where unnecessary strikes have been 
repeated.'   In London, Ryanair shares were trading at 11.88 euros, down 9.42 percent.      
Load-Date: October 1, 2018
End of Document
FTSE 100 Inches Higher On Brexit Hopes
FTSE 100 Inches Higher On Brexit Hopes
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
October 1, 2018 Monday 12:07 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 258 words
Body
       BRUSSELS/FRANKFURT/PARIS (dpa-AFX) - U.K. shares edged up slightly in cautious trade on Monday and 
the pound firmed up as investors monitored Brexit negotiations and global trade developments.  The pound rose 
after Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond said the European Union was in the mood to do a divorce deal, 
but uncertainty over Brexit had already hit the U.K.'s economy. 
 Elsewhere, the U.S. and Canada have reached an agreement on a framework North American Free Trade 
Agreement deal, an hour before a White House-imposed deadline of midnight on Sept 30.  The benchmark FTSE 
100 was up 0.2 percent at 7,523 in late opening deals after closing half a percent lower on Friday.   Tullow Oil 
advanced 1.6 percent and BP Plc rose over 1 percent as oil hovered close to its highest since November 2014.  
Mining giant Rio Tinto edged down slightly after announcing a $US1.55 billion ($2.1 billion) investment in two Robe 
River joint venture projects in the Pilbara, Western Australia.  Ryanair slumped almost 9 percent. The airline cut its 
forecast for full-year profit, citing rising oil prices and the impact of recent coordinated strikes across Europe.  Peer 
Easyjet tumbled 3.3 percent and BA owner IAG dropped 1.5 percent.   In economic releases, the U.K. 
manufacturing sector expanded at a faster pace in September, survey data from IHS Markit and Chartered Institute 
of Procurement & Supply showed.   The manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index rose to 53.8 in September 
from 53.0 in August, which was revised up from 52.8.      
Load-Date: October 1, 2018
End of Document
European Shares Rebound As US, Canada Reach Deal To Save NAFTA
European Shares Rebound As US, Canada Reach Deal To Save NAFTA
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
October 1, 2018 Monday 12:40 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 413 words
Body
       BRUSSELS/FRANKFURT/PARIS (dpa-AFX) - European stocks rebounded on Monday amid easing trade 
concerns after the U.S. and Canada reached an agreement on a framework North American Free Trade Agreement 
deal.  The pan-European Stoxx Europe 600 index was up 0.36 percent at 384.57 in late opening deals after 
declining 0.8 percent on Friday.   The German DAX was rising 0.7 percent, France's CAC 40 index was moving up 
0.3 percent and the U.K.'s FTSE 100 was marginally higher. 
  Swiss bakery business Aryzta soared as much as 32 percent. The company forecast stable underlying results in 
FY2019 after narrowing its fiscal 2018 loss.   ThyssenKrupp rose half a percent in Frankfurt after its supervisory 
board unanimously approved a plan to divide the group into two separate companies.  Linde AG advanced 1.3 
percent. The company has received approval for its proposed $83 billion merger with Praxair PX.N from the 
Chinese antitrust authority.  French supermarket group Casino gained 0.8 percent after it agreed to sell some 
property assets for 565 million euros to reduce debt levels.  Ryanair slumped almost 9 percent in London. The 
airline cut its forecast for full-year profit, citing rising oil prices and the impact of recent coordinated strikes across 
Europe.  Peer Easyjet tumbled 3.3 percent, BA owner IAG dropped 1.5 percent and Air-France KLM lost 2.5 
percent.   In economic releases, Eurozone manufacturing activity grew at the weakest pace in two years in 
September, final data from IHS Markit showed. The factory Purchasing Managers' Index fell to 53.2, the lowest 
since September 2016, from 54.6 in August. The initial estimate was 53.3.  The euro area jobless rate fell to 8.1 
percent in August from 8.2 percent in July, Eurostat reported. This was the lowest since November 2008.  German 
retail sales grew by real 1.6 percent year-on-year in August, faster than the 0.9 percent expansion seen a month 
ago, figures from Destatis showed. The annual rate came in line with expectations.  The U.K. manufacturing sector 
expanded at a faster pace in September, survey data from IHS Markit and Chartered Institute of Procurement & 
Supply showed.  The manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index rose to 53.8 in September from 53.0 in August, 
which was revised up from 52.8.  The pound rose after Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond said the 
European Union was in the mood to do a divorce deal, but uncertainty over Brexit had already hit the U.K.'s 
economy.      
European Shares Rebound As US, Canada Reach Deal To Save NAFTA

Ryanair predicts strike and Laudamotion costs
Ryanair predicts strike and Laudamotion costs
AirFinance Journal
October 2018
Copyright 2018 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 294 words
Byline: Alex Derber
Body
Strike action has caused Ryanair to lower its 2018/19 profit guidance by roughly 12% to between &euro;1.1 billion 
($1.28 billion) and &euro;1.2 billion.
Furthermore, the airline’s consolidated result should be lower still once Ryanair includes an estimated &euro;150 
million of start-up losses attributable to its recently acquired Laudamotion operation.
The Irish low-cost carrier blamed cabin and flight crew strikes across five countries in September as well as lower 
forward bookings due to fears of further industrial action for the reduction from its previous guidance of &euro;1.25 
billion to &euro;1.35.
“While we successfully managed five strikes by 25% of our Irish pilots this summer, two recent coordinated strikes 
by cabin crew and pilots across five EU countries has affected passenger numbers (through flight cancellations), 
close in bookings and yields (as we re-accommodate disrupted passengers), and forward air fares into Q3,” says 
Ryanair chief executive officer, Michael O’Leary.
In response to lower air fares and higher oil prices Ryanair will trim its winter 2018 capacity by 1%, and the airline 
warns that further capacity reductions may result from additional strike action. It adds that profit forecasts may be 
lowered again if more strikes occur in the third quarter.
O’Leary highlights “substantial progress” with labour negotiations in Ireland, the UK and Italy since it agreed to 
recognise unions in December 2017.
“Regrettably such progress has been impeded in Spain, Portugal, Germany, Holland, and Belgium where we’ve 
experienced interference in negotiations with our people and their unions, even when we offer them what they ask 
for (i.e. local contracts), in writing,” he adds.
Load-Date: February 12, 2019
End of Document
Turbulent summer cuts Ryanair profit
Turbulent summer cuts Ryanair profit
AirFinance Journal
October 2018
Copyright 2018 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 315 words
Byline: Alex Derber
Body
Big rises in staff and fuel costs cut into Ryanair’s margin for the first half of the year, despite a 27% increase in 
ancillary revenues.
The low-cost carrier transported 6% more passengers in the six months to 30 September, but saw its operating 
margin decline from 50% to 36%. Operating profit for H1 2018/19 was &euro;1.3 billion ($1.5 billion), compared with 
&euro;1.48 billion in the prior-year period.
During the first half Ryanair implemented a 20% increase to pilot wages and a 3% increase for non-flight staff.
Depreciation costs also rose, by 14% to &euro;319 million, as the carrier put an additional 53 owned aircraft on to 
its balance sheet.
Also weighing on costs was the airline’s takeover of Laudamotion, for which Ryanair predicts &euro;150 million of 
start-up losses for the full-year.
Overall, Ryanair’s first-half cash flow swung from &euro;313 million to negative &euro;222 million due to its poorer 
operating result.
Earlier in October, the airline lowered its full-year profit guidance by 12% to &euro;1.1 billion to &euro;1.2 billion – a 
forecast it has retained.
Disruption from strikes caused the airline to cut its forecast, and Ryanair says further industrial action is possible, 
“but we expect [its] impact to be very limited”.
Other concerns for the airline include Europe’s soft airfare environment and the possibility of further fuel price 
increases.
Ryanair has hedged 90% of its fuel requirements for the next 12 months at $68 per barrel.
“Full-year guidance remains heavily dependent on airfares not declining further (they remain soft this winter due to 
excess capacity in Europe), the impact of significantly higher oil prices on our unhedged exposures, the absence of 
unforeseen security events, ATC and other strikes and the impact of negative Brexit developments,” states Ryanair 
CEO Michael O’Leary.
Turbulent summer cuts Ryanair profit
Load-Date: February 12, 2019

FTSE manages monthly gain as Europe falls LONDON REPORT
FTSE manages monthly gain as Europe falls; LONDON REPORT
City A.M.
October 1, 2018 Monday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2018 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 20
Length: 330 words
Body
UK SHARES fell only slightly on Friday while bourses on the continent sustained heavy losses after the Italian 
government set a higher than expected budget deficit target that could put Rome on a collision course with 
Brussels.
The FTSE 100 fell 0.5 per cent while the Eurozone Stoxx 50 index lost 1.4 per cent and Milan sank 3.7 per cent. 
Insulated from concerns over Italy and the Eurozone, the top UK index ended the month with a one per cent gain 
but was down 1.6 per cent on the quarter after three months of turmoil in Brexit negotiations.
Financials weighed the most with RSA Insurance Group falling eight per cent after it reported an underwriting loss 
of about £70m in the third quarter due to bad weather, large losses and claims.
British insurers have taken a beating from a run of volatile weather, with the hottest summer in living memory 
following a blast of icy weather earlier in the year dubbed the "Beast from the East".
"Negatively, although the Solvency II coverage ratio is above its targeted range, management said these losses 
could impact the dividend growth decision for the full year," wrote KBW analysts.
Easyjet shares fell 0.9 per cent despite the budget carrier forecasting annual profit at the upper end of expectations, 
as it benefited from robust flight demand and cancellations at bigger rival Ryanair in 2018.
Randgold Resources ended the day up 3.6 per cent, the top FTSE 100 riser. Having fallen earlier in the session 
after Congo's state miner warned Randgold it would "assert its rights" in the DRC-based Kibali mine in the planned 
acquisition by Barrick Gold, the stock recovered after Randgold refuted the miner's claim.
Among mid-caps, outsourcer Serco was a top performer, up 11.8 per cent after it reported full-year profit and 
revenue above market expectations.
FTSE manages monthly gain as Europe falls LONDON REPORT
Tomorrow, Revolution Bars Group will report financial results, followed by Tesco's interim figures on Wednesday. 
DFS Furniture, DX and Ted Baker will all publish results on Thursday.

DFS Furniture will release financial results later this week

Ryanair warns earnings hurt by strikes, rising fuel cost
Ryanair warns earnings hurt by strikes, rising fuel cost
Associated Press Financial Wire
October 1, 2018 Monday 10:52 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 Associated Press All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS NEWS
Length: 138 words
Dateline: LONDON 
Body
LONDON (AP) - Ryanair, Europe's biggest airline by passengers, has issued a profit warning for the year amid 
strikes and rising fuel prices.
The low-cost carrier says Monday it has lowered its guidance by 12 percent to between 1.1 billion euros ($1.28 
billion) and 1.2 billion euros for the full year.
Pilot and cabin crew strikes in September hit passenger numbers and resulted in passenger compensation costs.
Ryanair Chief Executive Michael O'Leary says that while the strikes have been successfully managed "customer 
confidence, forward bookings and Q3 fares has been affected, most notably over the October school mid-terms and 
Christmas." Second and third-quarter traffic and airfares will be "somewhat lower than expected" as a result.
The airline says more staff strikes could force the company to issue further profit warnings.
Load-Date: October 2, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair profit warning grounds European funds
Ryanair profit warning grounds European funds
Citywire
October 1, 2018 Monday 12:21 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Citywire Financial Publishers All Rights Reserved
Length: 353 words
Byline: Daniel Grote
Highlight: Shares in budget airline group slump on profit warning, knocking European fund managers and FTSE 
100-listed rivals.
Body
 
Shares in Ryanair (RYA.I) have slumped after the budget airline group issued a profit warning as strikes by staff 
continue to take their toll on the business.
The shares slumped 9% to €11.94 as the group said full-year profits were likely to be 12% lower than previously 
forecast.
The news knocked shares in rival airliners. EasyJet (EZJ) fell to the bottom of a rising FTSE 100, down 2.6% at 
£12.81, as the index edged nine points higher to 7,519.
British Airways owner International Airlines Group (ICAG) was down 1% at 653.2p while on the FTSE 250, Wizz 
Air (WIZZ) fell 2.6% to £28.03.
Ryanair's fall will weigh on a number of Europe-focused fund managers with high conviction positions in the 
shares. 
Ryanair is the top holding for Citywire AA-rated Rory Powe in his £1.7 billion Man GLG Continental European 
Growth  fund, accounting for 6.2% of the portfolio.
Niall Gallagher holds 4% of the £1.7 billion GAM Star Continental European Equity  fund in the stock, while Citywire 
AAA-rated Stephen Paice, Moritz Sitte and Tom Walsh hold 3.4% of their £474 million Baillie Gifford European  
fund in Ryanair shares.
'A cocktail on problems has left Ryanair looking very weak and its shares trading at a two-year low,' said Russ 
Mould, investment director at AJ Bell.
'Strikes are disrupting its business and making individuals less confident over using Ryanair in the future in case 
their flights are also delayed or cancelled,' he added.
Ryanair profit warning grounds European funds
'Costs are going up, prices are coming down as a result of weaker forward bookings and now it has a surplus of 
winter cabin crew after cutting some flights.'
EasyJet was meanwhile joined at the bottom of the FTSE 100 by house builders, as the government announced 
plans for extra fees for foreign buyers of UK homes.
Berkeley (BKGH) fell 2.6% to £12.80, Persimmon (PSN) was down 1.7% at £23.25 and Taylor Wimpey (TW) fell 
1.1% to 170p.
On the FTSE 250, Bovis (BVS) was down 1.5% at £10.56 and Crest Nicholson (CRST) fell 1% to 346.6p.
Just Group (JUSTJ) was the biggest 'mid-cap' faller, down 5.7% at 83.4p as the annuity provider announced the 
departure of chief financial officer Simon Thomas.
Load-Date: October 1, 2018
End of Document
Royal Mail dives on 'shocking' profit warning
Royal Mail dives on 'shocking' profit warning
Citywire
October 1, 2018 Monday 4:45 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Citywire Financial Publishers All Rights Reserved
Length: 512 words
Byline: Daniel Grote
Highlight: Shares in Royal Mail dive on shock afternoon warning, with group alerting profits could fall by as much 
as 28%.
Body
 
Update: Shares in Royal Mail (RMG) have tumbled after the group warned profits could fall by as much as 28% this 
year and slashed its cost-cutting target.
The stock slumped 18% to 391.4p after the unscheduled trading update issued this afternoon. Royal Mail said 
profits could fall to as low as £500 million for the year, down from last year's £694 million.
Cost reduction targets have been cut from £230 million to £100 million as UK productivity performance languishes 
'significantly below plan'.
'Trading conditions in the UK are challenging,' said chief executive Rico Back.
'Our letter volumes, especially marketing mail, are impacted by ongoing structural decline, business uncertainty and 
GDPR.'
Helal Miah, investment research analyst at The Share Centre, said the news was 'shocking'.
'It seems that Rico Black is "throwing the baby out with the bath water" so that he can begin his tenure with a clean 
slate,' he said.

Ryanair Trims FY2019 Profit Guidance Due to Recent Strikes, Higher Fuel Costs
Ryanair Trims FY2019 Profit Guidance Due to Recent Strikes, Higher Fuel 
Costs
MT Newswires Live Briefs
October 1, 2018 Monday 4:43 AM EST
Copyright 2018 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 134 words
Body
 Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY) said pre-market Monday that it has lowered its FY2019 profit guidance to a range of 
EUR1.10 billion to EUR1.20 billion ($1.27 billion to $1.39 billion) from the previous range of EUR1.25 billion to 
EUR1.35 billion.
The Irish budget carrier said that the lowered guidance was due to lower traffic and weaker close-in fares due to 
recent strikes, higher care and re-accommodation costs, lower Q3 fares as forward bookings and higher energy 
prices. It also projected that Q2 & Q3 traffic and fares would be lower than expected largely as a result of the 
industrial action.
CEO Michael O'Leary also said that the company was reducing its winter 2018 capacity by 1% in response to the 
lower fare, higher oil and higher cost environment.

       BRUSSELS/FRANKFURT/PARIS (dpa-AFX) - French stocks bounced back from losses in the previous 
session on Monday amid easing trade concerns after the U.S. and Canada reached an agreement on a framework 
North American Free Trade Agreement deal.  The benchmark CAC 40 was up 15 points or 0.27 percent at 5,507 in 
opening deals after declining 0.9 percent on Friday.   Eurofins Scientific dropped 1.3 percent after it announced an 
agreement with the JSTI Group to acquire TestAmerica Environmental Services LLC.  Air-France KLM shares fell 
1.6 percent after rival Ryanair cut its forecast for full-year profit, citing rising oil prices and the impact of recent 
coordinated strikes across Europe.   Supermarket group Casino advanced 1.4 percent after it agreed to sell some

Lufthansa and Laudamotion settle leasing dispute
Lufthansa and Laudamotion settle leasing dispute
AirFinance Journal
October 2018
Copyright 2018 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 191 words
Byline: Michael Allen
Body
Lufthansa and Laudamotion have settled a dispute over leasing contracts, avoiding a London court hearing set for 
November.
To resolve the dispute, in the first half of 2019 the Austrian airline will return nine aircraft leased from Lufthansa.
“Deutsche Lufthansa AG and Laudamotion GmbH confirm that they have agreed that Laudamotion will redeliver the 
nine aircraft to Lufthansa by agreement on dates between 31 December 2018 and 30 June 2019 and on that basis 
the Parties have settled the litigation between them regarding the disputed termination of nine A320 and A321 
aircraft leases. The matter will not therefore be heard by the High Court in London in November 2018,” 
Laudamotion said in an statement seen by Airfinance Journal.
The German flag carrier said in July it wanted to end an agreement to lease aircraft to Laudamotion, claiming the 
Austrian leisure airline had failed to meet payments. Laudamotion rejected the allegations and a London court was 
scheduled to hear the case next month.
In August, Laudamotion's new owner, Ryanair, confirmed plans for the airline to receive nine additional Airbus A320 
aircraft by summer 2019.
Load-Date: February 12, 2019
End of Document
Genesis hires five executives
Genesis hires five executives
AirFinance Journal
October 2018
Copyright 2018 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 197 words
Byline: Jack Dutton
Body
Genesis has hired five executives for its aircraft leasing business.
The Irish lessor’s commercial team has expanded with the appointment of Pat Madigan as senior vice-president 
commercial and Peter O’Byrne as vice-president commercial.
Before joining Genesis, Madigan was part of the sales team at Shannon Engine Support, where he originated 
transactions globally for over a decade.
O’Byrne joined from Sky leasing where he held the position of vice-president technical. Before Sky Leasing, he 
spent 10 years with AWAS covering the technical and trading activities of the business.
DAE Capital's former vice-president technical, Aidan Cleary, has also joined Genesis as head of technical asset 
management. Cleary started his aviation career with Ryanair and has spent the last 14 years in the aircraft leasing 
sector.
In addition, Dave Curran joined the team as vice-president powerplant having worked as director engine 
management with Macquarie AirFinance.
Susan Cotter also joins the team as vice-president risk, having managed this business area previously for Apollo 
Aviation. Prior to Apollo, Cotter worked in the finance sector with Allied Irish Bank and Ulster Bank.

Ryanair employees showed courage by going on strike, union says
Ryanair employees showed courage by going on strike, union says
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 29, 2018 Saturday 1:23 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 260 words
Byline: Benedikt von Imhoff in Berlin
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
German labour union Verdi on Saturday hailed Ryanair flight attendants and pilots in Germany for their participation 
in a 24-hour Europe-wide strike, despite increasing pressure from their employer.
The airline staff's contribution to the strike was "all the more courageous because the employees participated 
despite great pressure," a Verdi spokeswoman told dpa on Saturday in Berlin.
Airline representatives had threatened to close locations ahead of the labour action, but the cabin crew and pilots 
were not deterred. The 24-hour strike ended overnight on Friday."We hope that Ryanair has understood the signal 
and finally puts a decent offer on the table," the Verdi spokeswoman said. The airline's staff is calling for increased 
wages and better working conditions in accordance with different countries' respective national laws.
The second Europe-wide strike by Ryanair pilots and flight attendants involved not only Germany, but also 
employees from Spain, Portugal, Belgium, Italy and the Netherlands.
At least 250 flights were cancelled on Friday due to the strike, constituting about 10 per cent of the Ryanair's 
scheduled European routes, the Irish airline said in Dublin.The Verdi spokeswoman also emphasized the support of 
local politicians, including Labour Minister Hubertus Heil, who met striking employees in Berlin.
"This support encourages employees," she said, while adding that even some travellers have shown interest and 
understanding at affected airports.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Martin Waldman, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Ryanair employees showed courage by going on strike, union says
Load-Date: September 30, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair employees showed courage by going on strike, union says
Ryanair employees showed courage by going on strike, union says
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
September 29, 2018 Saturday 1:24 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 256 words
Body
       BERLIN (dpa-AFX) - German labour union Verdi on Saturday hailed Ryanair flight attendants and pilots in 
Germany for their participation in a 24-hour Europe-wide strike, despite increasing pressure from their employer.  
The airline staff's contribution to the strike was 'all the more courageous because the employees participated 
despite great pressure,' a Verdi spokeswoman told dpa on Saturday in Berlin. 
  Airline representatives had threatened to close locations ahead of the labour action, but the cabin crew and pilots 
were not deterred. The 24-hour strike ended overnight on Friday.  'We hope that Ryanair has understood the signal 
and finally puts a decent offer on the table,' the Verdi spokeswoman said. The airline's staff is calling for increased 
wages and better working conditions in accordance with different countries' respective national laws.   The second 
Europe-wide strike by Ryanair pilots and flight attendants involved not only Germany, but also employees from 
Spain, Portugal, Belgium, Italy and the Netherlands.   At least 250 flights were cancelled on Friday due to the strike, 
constituting about 10 per cent of the Ryanair's scheduled European routes, the Irish airline said in Dublin.  The 
Verdi spokeswoman also emphasized the support of local politicians, including Labour Minister Hubertus Heil, who 
met striking employees in Berlin.   'This support encourages employees,' she said, while adding that even some 
travellers have shown interest and understanding at affected airports.   Copyright dpa    
Load-Date: September 29, 2018
End of Document
Strike forces Ryanair to cancel 250 flights Airlines ; Chief under pressure after pledge to settle disputes by 
Christmas
Strike forces Ryanair to cancel 250 flights; Airlines ; Chief under pressure 
after pledge to settle disputes by Christmas
Financial Times (London, England)
September 29, 2018 Saturday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 18
Length: 439 words
Byline: ARTHUR BEESLEY ;NAOMI ROVNICK
Body
Ryanair cancelled flights yesterday due to a 24-hour walkout by pilots and cabin crew in Belgium, the Netherlands, 
Portugal, Italy and Germany. A year after a rostering crisis that led the European budget carrier to recognise 
unions, it is still struggling with demands for better pay and conditions in large parts of its network. The industrial 
action has hit investor confidence in the company's leadership.
A growing investor protest led almost 30 per cent of shareholders to reject the re-election last week of David 
Bonderman, the US private equity tycoon who has chaired the airline for 22 years.
About 250 flights were cancelled, piling pressure on Michael O'Leary, chief executive, to make good on his promise 
to settle the disputes by Christmas.
The airline was hit by a wave of strikes during the summer, among them a walkout in five countries that led to the 
cancellation of 400 flights on August 10.
Passengers who were affected yesterday received text messages and emails from Ryanair. They can either apply 
for a refund or take another flight, but the carrier said it was not required to pay compensation under EU rules 
because the strikes were beyond its control.
Strike forces Ryanair to cancel 250 flights Airlines ; Chief under pressure after pledge to settle disputes by 
Christmas
The Dublin-based airline has entered into agreements with crew in Ireland, Italy and Britain, and has a recognition 
deal with one German union.
Mr O'Leary said Ryanair would not "roll over" in the face of industrial action, adding that pay increases would add 
(EURO)200m to annual costs.
Some unions have pushed for crew to be hired under local, rather that Irish, law. Mr O'Leary has said the company 
has lobbied Dublin to change the double taxation treaties that require it to employ crew under Irish law in line with 
its registration of aircraft.
At the same time, Ryanair blamed workers at rival airlines for stoking the disputes. In a complaint this week to the 
European Commission, Ryanair said its talks with staff in some countries were being impeded by a "collective 
campaign" involving the European Cockpit Association and the International Transport Workers' Federation.
Peter Bellow, Ryanair's chief operations officer, said yesterday that Germany's VC union, which had urged the 
German pilots to walk out, was "controlled" by Lufthansa, its competitor. Mr Bellow also said it had agreed to 
arbitration with the VC union over pay and conditions. "This is another example of a strike being organised in 
Ryanair by association, by a union controlled by competitor airline employees, despite the fact that Ryanair has 
agreed to arbitration," he said.
There were fresh demands from shareholders yesterday for the airline to get ahead of the disputes.
See Lex
Load-Date: September 28, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair : lairy O'Leary
Ryanair: lairy O'Leary
Financial Times (London, England)
September 29, 2018 Saturday
Edition 1, Asian Edition
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 20
Length: 318 words
Body
Ryanair's swagger used to be justified. The airline's reliability, low costs and the chutzpah of its leadership helped it 
become Europe's largest by passenger numbers. But it lost that crown in 2017.
Over the past year, the company's share price has dropped by a fifth, even though that of its rival easyJet rose by a 
tenth. Some of Ryanair's traditional strengths have started to look like sources of weakness.
Consider its tight lid on labour expenses. Yesterday, strikes disrupted 250 of its flights, in the latest wave of 
cancellations since a pilot rostering crisis blew up a year ago. Boss Michael O'Leary once said he would rather cut 
off his own hands than recognise a union. He relented last December but tensions continue to simmer.
There might be an upside to recognising unions. Doing so in France, for example, paved the way for an expansion 
unveiled this week.
But the shift of power to pilots is pushing up costs. Operating profit margins fell by 3 percentage points last year to 
22 per cent. Staff costs per employee were (EURO)5.30 per passenger in 2017 and are likely to rise to (EURO)7 by 
2020. With rising bills for fuel, profits are unlikely to increase over the next couple of years.
The staffing problems have put a spotlight on Ryanair's governance failings. Mr O'Leary's brash comments have 
inflamed disputes with workers. A more independent board would tell him to tone it down a bit. Chairman David 
Bonderman, in place for 22 years, was re-elected this month despite a shareholder protest. Investors need to be 
confident that the next chairman will stand up to the CEO.
Ryanair : lairy O'Leary
Ryanair is still a solid business. Its ample liquidity should allow it to weather the disruption caused by a disruptive 
Brexit. It thinks it has a good chance of reclaiming the title of Europe's largest airline this year, from Lufthansa. But 
some of the gloss has come off the model. A little humility would not go amiss.
Load-Date: September 28, 2018
End of Document
