Ryanair Holdings plc ( RYAAY ) Position Cut by Renaissance Technologies LLC
Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY) Position Cut by Renaissance Technologies 
LLC
American Banking and Market News
September 4, 2018 Tuesday
Copyright 2018 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 571 words
Body
Ryanair logo Renaissance Technologies LLC lowered its holdings in shares of  Ryanair Holdings plc 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 11.8% in the second quarter, according to the company in its most recent 13F filing with the 
Securities & Exchange Commission. The firm owned 2,766,408 shares of the transportation company's stock after 
selling 369,300 shares during the quarter. Renaissance Technologies LLC owned 1.18% of Ryanair worth 
$316,007,000 as of its most recent SEC filing.  
Other institutional investors and hedge funds have also bought and sold shares of the company. Private Advisor 
Group LLC bought a new stake in  Ryanair during the 1st quarter valued at $248,000.  Perigon Wealth 
Management LLC bought a new stake in  Ryanair during the 1st quarter valued at $254,000.  Oppenheimer Asset 
Management Inc. bought a new stake in  Ryanair during the 1st quarter valued at $346,000.  CIBC World Markets 
Inc. bought a new stake in  Ryanair during the 1st quarter valued at $350,000.  Finally, Lucia Wealth Services LLC 
bought a new stake in  Ryanair during the 2nd quarter valued at $408,000. Institutional investors own  43.95% of 
the company's stock.  
Several research analysts have recently commented on RYAAY shares. ValuEngine  lowered Ryanair from a "hold" 
rating to a "sell" rating in a research report on Tuesday, July 24th. BidaskClub lowered Ryanair from a "strong-buy" 
rating to a "buy" rating in a research report on Monday, May 14th. Raymond James lowered Ryanair from an 
"outperform" rating to a "market perform" rating in a research report on Thursday, August 9th. Deutsche Bank 
lowered Ryanair from a "buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a research report on Thursday, June 7th. Finally, Royal 
Bank of Canada  reaffirmed a "buy" rating on shares of Ryanair in a research report on Thursday, August 16th. Five 
analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, six have given a hold rating and three have issued  a buy rating to 
the stock. The company  has an average rating of "Hold" and a consensus target price of $138.00. 
Shares of NASDAQ:RYAAY  opened at $101.87 on Tuesday. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 1 year low of $94.50 and 
a 1 year high of $127.61. The stock has a market cap of $23.86 billion, a P/E ratio of 14.45 and a beta of 0.55. The 
company has a current ratio of 1.12, a quick ratio of 1.12 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.72.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last announced its earnings results on Monday, July 23rd. The transportation company 
reported $1.62 earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, beating the Thomson Reuters' consensus estimate of 
$1.55 by $0.07. Ryanair had a return on equity of 29.19% and a net margin of 18.47%. The company had revenue 
of $2.48 billion for the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of $2.41 billion.  research analysts expect that  
Ryanair Holdings plc will post 6.28 EPS for the current fiscal year.  
Ryanair Holdings plc ( RYAAY ) Position Cut by Renaissance Technologies LLC
About Ryanair
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

Institutional Ownership by Quarter for Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY)

Ryanair hits at UK air traffic control service Airlines
Ryanair hits at UK air traffic control service; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
September 4, 2018 Tuesday
Edition 1, Asian Edition
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;NEWS; Pg. 12
Length: 284 words
Byline: JOSH SPERO
Body
Ryanair has accused Britain's air traffic control service of "blatant discrimination" against it and other airlines at 
Stansted airport as it announced it was submitting a complaint to the European Commission.
It highlighted figures from the Civil Aviation Authority showing that 52 per cent of air traffic delays at airports in 
London in the first quarter happened at Stansted, where Ryanair has its largest base and runs 65 per cent of the 
airport's services.
Luton airport had 30 per cent of the delays while Heathrow had none, prompting Ryanair to claim that NATS, the air 
traffic control manager, had given Heathrow "special treatment".
The carrier said it was submitting complaints to the European Commission and to the CAA to stir them into action, 
but it declined to provide a copy of the commission complaint.
Stansted said it was also considering making a complaint to the CAA about what it called the airport's 
"disproportionate share of ATC delays". It is not the first complaint Ryanair has filed with the commission in the past 
few months. In July, alongside IAG, easyJet and Wizz Air, it submitted a complaint saying the commission should 
act over French air traffic control strikes and shortages, claiming they breached "the fundamental principle of free 
movement within the EU".
Ryanair hits at UK air traffic control service Airlines
Peter Bellew, Ryanair's chief operating officer, said: "We call on the UK Department for Transport and the European 
Commission to take urgent action to ensure that [NATS] is fully staffed and treats each London airport fairly. NATS 
don't have enough staff."
NATS said staffing numbers would not make a difference and the introduction of new technology, delivered at other 
airports too, had caused Stansted's problems.
Load-Date: September 3, 2018
End of Document

Load-Date: September 3, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair claims to be victim of 'blatant' air traffic control discrimination Airlines
Ryanair claims to be victim of 'blatant' air traffic control discrimination; 
Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
September 4, 2018 Tuesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;BUSINESS; Pg. 17
Length: 452 words
Byline: JOSH SPERO
Body
Ryanair has accused Britain's air traffic control service of "blatant discrimination" against it and other airlines at 
Stansted airport as it announced it was submitting a complaint to the European Commission.
It highlighted figures from the Civil Aviation Authority showing that 52 per cent of air traffic delays at airports in 
London in the first quarter happened at Stansted, where Ryanair has its largest base and runs 65 per cent of the 
airport's services.
Luton airport had 30 per cent of the delays while Heathrow had none, prompting Ryanair to claim that NATS, the air 
traffic control manager, had given Heathrow "special treatment".
The carrier said it was submitting complaints to the European Commission and to the CAA to stir them into action, 
but it declined to provide a copy of the commission complaint.
Stansted said it was also considering making a complaint to the CAA about what it called the airport's 
"disproportionate share of ATC delays". It is not the first complaint Ryanair has filed with the commission in the past 
few months. In July, alongside IAG, easyJet and Wizz Air, it submitted a complaint saying the commission should 
act over French air traffic control strikes and shortages, claiming they breached "the fundamental principle of free 
movement within the EU".
Ryanair claims to be victim of 'blatant' air traffic control discrimination Airlines
Peter Bellew, Ryanair's chief operating officer, said: "We call on the UK Department for Transport and the European 
Commission to take urgent action to ensure that [NATS] is fully staffed and treats each London airport fairly. NATS 
don't have enough staff."
NATS said staffing numbers would not make a difference and the introduction of new technology, delivered at other 
airports too, had caused Stansted's problems.
"All airlines and airports were notified of the timetable in advance and understood the new technology will help us 
increase capacity safely in the future. NATS does not discriminate between airlines or airports."
In 2017, Gatwick airport suffered the most delays (34 per cent), with Stansted close behind (28 per cent). Last year 
Stansted had 26m passengers and 190,000 flights.
This is not the first time Ryanair has accused NATS of neglecting its duty.
In 2016, together with Stansted airport, it instigated an investigation by the CAA after saying NATS had "unduly 
preferred" certain airports, thus "preventing, restricting or distorting competition".
In its report, the CAA found "no evidence" of undue preference or discrimination but said NATS did need to take 
remedial action regarding staffing shortfalls. The CAA said it would consider any new complaint when it had been 
received.
Ryanair's first-quarter results showed air traffic control problems forced the airline to cancel more than 2,500 flights.
Graphic
 
The carrier has complained to the European Commission and the CAA
Load-Date: September 3, 2018

lowered its holdings in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 11.8% in the second quarter,

2,766,408 shares of the transportation company's stock after selling 369,300 shares during the quarter. 
Renaissance Technologies LLC owned 1.18% of Ryanair worth $316,007,000 as of its most recent SEC filing. 
Other institutional investors and hedge funds have also bought and sold shares of the company. Private Advisor

Inc. bought a new stake in Ryanair during the 1st quarter valued at $346,000. CIBC World Markets Inc. bought a 
new stake in Ryanair during the 1st quarter valued at $350,000. Finally, Lucia Wealth Services LLC bought a new 
stake in Ryanair during the 2nd quarter valued at $408,000. Institutional investors own 43.95% of the company's 
stock. Several research analysts have recently commented on RYAAY shares. ValuEngine[1] lowered Ryanair from 
a "hold" rating to a "sell" rating in a research report on Tuesday, July 24th. BidaskClub lowered Ryanair from a 
"strong-buy" rating to a "buy" rating in a research report on Monday, May 14th. Raymond James lowered Ryanair 
from an "outperform" rating to a "market perform" rating in a research report on Thursday, August 9th. Deutsche 
Bank lowered Ryanair from a "buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a research report on Thursday, June 7th. Finally, 
Royal Bank of Canada reaffirmed a "buy" rating on shares of Ryanair in a research report on Thursday, August 
16th. Five analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, six have given a hold rating and three have issued a buy 
rating to the stock. The company has an average rating of "Hold" and a consensus target price of $138.00.Shares

company has a current ratio of 1.12, a quick ratio of 1.12 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.72. Ryanair

Ryanair Reports 9% Increase in Aug Passenger Numbers Despite Staff Shortage, Pilot Strike
Ryanair Reports 9% Increase in Aug Passenger Numbers Despite Staff 
Shortage, Pilot Strike
MT Newswires Live Briefs
September 4, 2018 Tuesday 5:16 AM EST
Copyright 2018 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 84 words
Body
 Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY) said pre-market Tuesday that total August traffic expanded 9% to 13.8 million 
passengers with a 97% load factor.
The company also said that Ryanair traffic increased 5% to 13.3 million passengers with a 97% load factor
The Irish budget airliner also conceded that over 100,000 passengers had their flights cancelled last month 
because of repeated staff shortages in the UK, Germany and France, and due to a single day of pilot strike.

Ryanair Holdings Aug. Total Customer Traffic Up 9% YoY
Ryanair Holdings Aug. Total Customer Traffic Up 9% YoY
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
September 4, 2018 Tuesday 8:57 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 175 words
Body
       BRUSSELS/FRANKFURT/PARIS (dpa-AFX) - Ryanair Holdings plc (RYA.L, RYAAY) reported that its August 
total traffic (which included Lauda traffic for the first time) grew by 9% to 13.8 million customers, while load factor 
was unchanged at 97%, on the back of even lower fares. Ryanair traffic grew 5% to 13.3 million customers with a 
97% load factor. Lauda traffic was 0.5 million customers with a 92% load factor.   Ryanair's Kenny Jacobs said: 
'Regrettably, over 100,000 Ryanair customers had their flights cancelled in August because of repeated ATC staff 
shortages in the UK, Germany and France, and one day of unnecessary pilot strikes. Ryanair, together with other 
European airlines, calls for urgent action by the EU Commission and Governments to correct these ATC staff 
shortages which are disrupting the travel plans of millions of Europe's consumers this summer.'  The Group noted 
that the ATC staff shortages and the pilot strike on 10 Aug caused almost 550 flight cancellations in August 
compared to 27 cancellations in August, 2017.

Great West Life Assurance Co. Can Purchases 38,913 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( RYAAY )
Great West Life Assurance Co. Can Purchases 38,913 Shares of Ryanair 
Holdings plc (RYAAY)
American Banking and Market News
September 3, 2018 Monday
Copyright 2018 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 710 words
Body
Ryanair logo Great West Life Assurance Co. Can raised its position in  Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 
30.5% in the 2nd quarter, according to its most recent Form 13F filing with the Securities & Exchange Commission. 
The institutional investor  owned 166,461 shares of the transportation company's stock after acquiring an additional 
38,913 shares during the quarter. Great West Life Assurance Co. Can owned 0.07% of Ryanair worth $19,008,000 
at the end of the most recent quarter.  
A number of other large investors have also recently modified their holdings of RYAAY. Mitsubishi UFJ Kokusai 
Asset Management Co. Ltd. lifted its holdings in shares of  Ryanair by 1,804.1% during the 2nd quarter. Mitsubishi 
UFJ Kokusai Asset Management Co. Ltd. now owns 12,643 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at 
$1,444,000 after buying an additional 11,979 shares during the last quarter.  Lucia Wealth Services LLC acquired a 
new stake in shares of  Ryanair during the 2nd quarter valued at about $408,000.  JCIC Asset Management Inc. 
lifted its holdings in shares of  Ryanair by 32.8% during the 2nd quarter. JCIC Asset Management Inc. now owns 
26,723 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $3,053,000 after buying an additional 6,596 shares 
during the last quarter.  Sei Investments Co. lifted its holdings in shares of  Ryanair by 40.7% during the 2nd 
quarter. Sei Investments Co. now owns 83,012 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $9,483,000 
after buying an additional 24,022 shares during the last quarter.  Finally, Commonwealth of Pennsylvania Public 
School Empls Retrmt SYS acquired a new stake in shares of  Ryanair during the 2nd quarter valued at about 
$23,704,000. 43.95% of the stock is owned by institutional investors.  
Shares of NASDAQ:RYAAY  opened at $101.87 on Monday. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 1-year low of $94.50 and a 
1-year high of $127.61. The company has a market cap of $23.86 billion, a PE ratio of 14.45 and a beta of 0.55. 
The company has a current ratio of 1.12, a quick ratio of 1.12 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.72.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last announced its quarterly earnings data on Monday, July 23rd. The transportation 
company reported $1.62 earnings per share for the quarter, topping the Thomson Reuters' consensus estimate of 
$1.55 by $0.07. The company had revenue of $2.48 billion for the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of $2.41 
billion. Ryanair had a return on equity of 29.19% and a net margin of 18.47%.  research analysts expect that  
Ryanair Holdings plc will post 6.28 EPS for the current year.  
A number of research analysts recently weighed in on the company. Royal Bank of Canada  reissued a "buy" rating 
on shares of Ryanair in a research note on Thursday, August 16th. UBS Group  reissued a "buy" rating on shares 
of Ryanair in a research note on Wednesday, August 15th. Raymond James downgraded Ryanair from an 
Great West Life Assurance Co. Can Purchases 38,913 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( RYAAY )
"outperform" rating to a "market perform" rating in a research note on Thursday, August 9th. BidaskClub 
downgraded Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "sell" rating in a research note on Tuesday, August 7th. Finally, 
ValuEngine  downgraded Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "sell" rating in a research note on Tuesday, July 24th. 
Five equities research analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, six have given a hold rating and three have 
assigned  a buy rating to the company. The company presently has a consensus rating of "Hold" and a consensus 
target price of $138.00. 
About Ryanair
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

Ryanair chairman re-elected despite opposition
Ryanair chairman re-elected despite opposition
AirFinance Journal
September 2018
Copyright 2018 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 215 words
Byline: Michael Allen
Body
Ryanair has rejected investor pressure for the departure of long-serving chairman David Bonderman after a 
significant shareholder protest, the Financial Times reports.    Bonderman, who has been chairman for 22 years, 
was re-elected to the board with support of 70.5% of shareholders at the company’s annual meeting, the 
newspaper reports.
Chief executive officer Michael O’Leary said the “overwhelming” level of support for Bonderman’s re-election would 
make a politician happy. Still, he doubted whether the chairman would stay for another two years.   “He knows it 
won’t go on forever. We know it won’t go on forever,” O’Leary told reporters after the meeting.    “But frankly if we 
could encourage him to continue to chair the company for another couple of years, I personally would encourage 
him to do so. I don’t think he will.”   Bloomberg reported on 5 September that Bonderman was facing increasing 
opposition to his re-election. The ITF and ETF international labour groups and investor-advisory service Glass 
Lewis were separately lobbying against the reappointment of Bonderman, a long-time ally of chief executive officer 
Michael O’Leary and leader of the Ryanair board since 1996, the newswire adds.
Load-Date: February 12, 2019
End of Document
All on board survive Utair 737-800 excursion at Sochi;  E All 170 occupants of a Utair Boeing 737-800 have 
escaped after the aircraft suffered severe damage dur....
All on board survive Utair 737-800 excursion at Sochi;  E All 170 occupants 
of a Utair Boeing 737-800 have escaped after the aircraft suffered severe 
damage during an overrun on landing at Sochi.
Flight International
September 1, 2018
Copyright 2018 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: FLIGHTGLOBAL.COM
Length: 272 words
Body
All 170 occupants of a Utair Boeing 737-800 have escaped after the aircraft suffered severe damage during an 
overrun on landing at Sochi.
The aircraft, operating flight UT579 from Moscow, appears to have conducted a missed approach before landing on 
runway 06 just before 03:00 on 1 September.
Utair says the aircraft (VQ-BJI) suffered a runway excursion and its landing gear collapsed, before it came to a halt 
in a river bed.
The left-hand CFM International CFM56 engine ignited, the carrier adds.
Slides were deployed and all 164 passengers and six crew members were evacuated. Utair says all 170 on board 
survived the accident.
Meteorological data from Sochi airport indicates that it had been experiencing thunderstorms and rain, and wind 
gusts exceeding 40kt.
Weather data shortly after the landing indicates a wind direction from the south-west, suggesting a tailwind for 
aircraft landing on runway 06.
The Interstate Aviation Committee says it has established a commission to investigate the accident.
“As a result of the [excursion] and subsequent fire, the aircraft was seriously damaged,” it states.
NOTAM information issued for Sochi airport after the accident states that the ILS for runway 06/24 is now 
unserviceable as a result of emergency work in the critical area.
All on board survive Utair 737-800 excursion at Sochi;  E All 170 occupants of a Utair Boeing 737-800 have 
escaped after the aircraft suffered severe damage dur....
Russia’s emergency services ministry for the Krasnodar region says that it was informed of the accident at 02:59 
and that, by 03:15, the fire had been extinguished.
Flight Fleets Analyzer lists VQ-BJI as a 16-year old airframe, originally delivered to Ryanair, and also previously 
used by Moskva Airlines. It indicates that the jet is owned by SB Leasing Ireland.
Load-Date: September 1, 2018
End of Document
Big carriers can handle disorderly Brexit: Moody's
Big carriers can handle disorderly Brexit: Moody's
AirFinance Journal
September 2018
Copyright 2018 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 288 words
Byline: Alex Derber
Body
If Britain leaves the European Union without an exit deal, airlines could struggle to raise fares, boost traffic and 
lower costs, ratings agency Moody’s has warned.
Nonetheless, Britain and Ireland’s largest carriers should weather any damage from a no-deal Brexit “even if flights 
are disrupted for an extended period” it has concluded.
British Airways, Ryanair and Easyjet should have the flexibility to survive a no-deal Brexit, although Moody’s warns 
that smaller airlines and those with weak liquidity could see their credit ratings downgraded.
“Broadly, an airline will be less exposed if it has a more flexible operating model and cost structure, greater network 
diversification and scale, and has begun to implement contingency measures,” Moody’s says.
The ratings agency identifies main risks from Britain exiting the European Union without a deal: a loss of traffic 
rights between the UK and the European Common Aviation Area (ECAA); a loss of traffic rights between the UK 
and countries that have aviation agreements with the EU, such as the US; meeting ownership and control 
conditions to retain valid operating licences; the UK's continued membership of the European Aviation Safety 
Agency; and weaker macroeconomic conditions.
“The probability of these risks occurring in a no-deal scenario and their effect on credit quality will differ depending 
on the political willingness and economic incentives to separate a no-deal Brexit from aviation agreements, as well 
as contingency plans and past exceptions to rules or regulations,” notes Moody’s.
Earlier this week the British government said that flights would probably continue even in the event of no deal.
Load-Date: February 12, 2019
End of Document

Ryanair launch weekend mega sale
Ryanair launch weekend mega sale
Business World (Digest)
August 31, 2018 Friday
Copyright 2018 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: GENERAL
Length: 128 words
Byline: Robert McHugh
Body
Ryanair has launched a massive weekend ‘Mega Sale’, with up to €30 off return flights across its European 
network, allowing customers to book an autumn break or winter getaway on lower fares.
This seat sale is available for travel between September and January and can only be found on the Ryanair.com 
website, but seats must be booked by midnight Monday (3 Sept).
Speaking today, Ryanair’s Robin Kiely said, "This weekend we’ve slashed fares by up to €30 on return flights 
across our European network for travel between September and January, so there’s never been a better time to 
book an autumn break or winter getaway. This amazing offer will end at midnight (24:00hrs) on Monday, so 
customers should log on quickly and bag a bargain break."
Source: www.businessworld.ie

Janus Henderson Group PLC Sells 23,217 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( RYAAY )
Janus Henderson Group PLC Sells 23,217 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc 
(RYAAY)
American Banking and Market News
August 30, 2018 Thursday
Copyright 2018 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 729 words
Body
Ryanair logo Janus Henderson Group PLC cut its position in shares of  Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 
0.9% in the second quarter, according to the company in its most recent disclosure with the Securities and 
Exchange Commission (SEC). The institutional investor  owned 2,570,816 shares of the transportation company's 
stock after selling 23,217 shares during the quarter. Janus Henderson Group PLC owned approximately 1.10% of 
Ryanair worth $293,663,000 at the end of the most recent quarter.  
Other hedge funds and other institutional investors have also recently modified their holdings of the company. Wells 
Fargo & Company MN boosted its stake in  Ryanair by 5.8% during the first quarter. Wells Fargo & Company MN 
now owns 411,079 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $50,500,000 after buying an additional 
22,436 shares during the period.  Lester Murray Antman dba SimplyRich boosted its stake in  Ryanair by 10.7% 
during the first quarter. Lester Murray Antman dba SimplyRich now owns 8,601 shares of the transportation 
company's stock valued at $1,057,000 after buying an additional 832 shares during the period.  Comerica Bank 
boosted its stake in  Ryanair by 3.4% during the first quarter. Comerica Bank now owns 15,202 shares of the 
transportation company's stock valued at $1,756,000 after buying an additional 494 shares during the period.  
Massachusetts Financial Services Co. MA boosted its stake in  Ryanair by 53.3% during the first quarter. 
Massachusetts Financial Services Co. MA now owns 2,217,338 shares of the transportation company's stock 
valued at $272,400,000 after buying an additional 770,774 shares during the period.  Finally, Mitchell Capital 
Management Co. bought a new stake in  Ryanair during the first quarter valued at $443,000. Institutional investors 
and hedge funds own  43.94% of the company's stock.  
Several equities research analysts recently issued reports on RYAAY shares. ValuEngine  lowered Ryanair from a 
"buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a research note on Wednesday, May 9th. BidaskClub lowered Ryanair from a 
"strong-buy" rating to a "buy" rating in a research note on Monday, May 14th. Deutsche Bank  reaffirmed a "buy" 
rating on shares of Ryanair in a research note on Tuesday, May 22nd. BNP Paribas lowered Ryanair from an 
"outperform" rating to a "neutral" rating in a research note on Thursday, June 7th. Finally, Exane BNP Paribas 
lowered Ryanair from an "outperform" rating to a "neutral" rating in a research note on Thursday, June 7th. Five 
research analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, six have given a hold rating and three have given a buy 
rating to the company's stock. Ryanair presently has an average rating of "Hold" and a consensus target price of 
$138.00. 
Janus Henderson Group PLC Sells 23,217 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( RYAAY )
Shares of RYAAY stock  opened at $102.29 on Thursday. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.72, a current 
ratio of 1.12 and a quick ratio of 1.12. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 12-month low of $94.50 and a 12-month high of 
$127.61. The stock has a market cap of $23.35 billion, a price-to-earnings ratio of 14.51 and a beta of 0.64.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last issued its quarterly earnings results on Monday, July 23rd. The transportation 
company reported $1.62 earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, topping the Thomson Reuters' consensus 
estimate of $1.55 by $0.07. Ryanair had a return on equity of 29.19% and a net margin of 18.47%. The firm had 
revenue of $2.48 billion during the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of $2.41 billion.  equities research 
analysts anticipate that  Ryanair Holdings plc will post 6.28 earnings per share for the current fiscal year.  
Ryanair Company Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, continental Europe, Morocco, and Israel. It also offers various ancillary services, such as non-flight 
scheduled services and Internet-related services; and markets accommodation services and travel insurance 
through its Website, as well as engages in the in-flight sale of beverages, food, and merchandise.

Ryanair Signs Fourth Cabin Crew Union Recognition Agreement With Forsa
Ryanair Signs Fourth Cabin Crew Union Recognition Agreement With Forsa
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
August 30, 2018 Thursday 2:51 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 102 words
Body
       WASHINGTON (dpa-AFX) - Ryanair Holdings Plc. (RYA.L, RYAAY) said that it has signed its fourth cabin crew 
union recognition agreement with Forsa, who will be the representative body for Ryanair's directly employed cabin 
crew in Ireland.  Ryanair said it looks forward to working with Forsa and the elected Ryanair (Cabin Crew) Company 
Council to conclude an early CLA for Ryanair's directly employed cabin crew based in Ireland. This agreement 
follows Ryanair's cabin crew recognition deals with the Italian ANPAC, ANPAV and Fit-Cisl unions, UNITE the 
union in the UK and the Ver.di union in Germany.      
Load-Date: August 30, 2018
End of Document

14.69 and a beta of 0.64. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 1 year low of $94.50 and a 1 year high of $127.61. The 
company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.72, a current ratio of 1.12 and a quick ratio of 1.12.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last issued its quarterly earnings data on Monday, July 23rd. The transportation 
company reported $1.62 earnings per share for the quarter, topping analysts' consensus estimates of $1.55 by 
$0.07. The business had revenue of $2.48 billion during the quarter, compared to the consensus estimate of $2.41 
billion. Ryanair had a net margin of 18.47% and a return on equity of 29.19%.  equities analysts predict that  
Ryanair Holdings plc will post 6.28 EPS for the current fiscal year.  
About Ryanair
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, continental Europe, Morocco, and Israel. It also offers various ancillary services, such as non-flight 
scheduled services and Internet-related services; and markets accommodation services and travel insurance 
through its Website, as well as engages in the in-flight sale of beverages, food, and merchandise.

Fmr LLC Sells 1,167,280 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( RYAAY )
Fmr LLC Sells 1,167,280 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY)
American Banking and Market News
August 29, 2018 Wednesday
Copyright 2018 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 712 words
Body
Ryanair logo Fmr LLC trimmed its position in  Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 9.4% during the second 
quarter, according to its most recent 13F filing with the SEC. The fund owned 11,297,569 shares of the 
transportation company's stock after selling 1,167,280 shares during the period. Fmr LLC owned about 4.82% of 
Ryanair worth $1,290,521,000 as of its most recent filing with the SEC.  
A number of other institutional investors and hedge funds have also recently made changes to their positions in 
RYAAY. Massachusetts Financial Services Co. MA boosted its position in shares of  Ryanair by 53.3% in the 1st 
quarter. Massachusetts Financial Services Co. MA now owns 2,217,338 shares of the transportation company's 
stock worth $272,400,000 after purchasing an additional 770,774 shares during the last quarter.  FIL Ltd boosted its 
position in shares of  Ryanair by 659.3% in the 1st quarter. FIL Ltd now owns 575,221 shares of the transportation 
company's stock worth $70,665,000 after purchasing an additional 499,469 shares during the last quarter.  
Thornburg Investment Management Inc. boosted its position in shares of  Ryanair by 20.4% in the 1st quarter. 
Thornburg Investment Management Inc. now owns 1,973,942 shares of the transportation company's stock worth 
$242,499,000 after purchasing an additional 334,623 shares during the last quarter.  Commonwealth of 
Pennsylvania Public School Empls Retrmt SYS bought a new position in shares of  Ryanair in the 2nd quarter worth 
$23,704,000.  Finally, WCM Investment Management CA boosted its position in shares of  Ryanair by 5.2% in the 
1st quarter. WCM Investment Management CA now owns 3,719,251 shares of the transportation company's stock 
worth $456,910,000 after purchasing an additional 185,253 shares during the last quarter. Hedge funds and other 
institutional investors own  43.94% of the company's stock.  
RYAAY has been the topic of several research analyst reports. BidaskClub raised Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a 
"buy" rating in a research note on Monday, June 25th. Deutsche Bank  reissued a "buy" rating on shares of Ryanair 
in a research note on Tuesday, May 22nd. UBS Group  reissued a "buy" rating on shares of Ryanair in a research 
note on Wednesday, August 15th. Royal Bank of Canada  reissued a "buy" rating on shares of Ryanair in a 
research note on Thursday, August 16th. Finally, Exane BNP Paribas downgraded Ryanair from an "outperform" 
rating to a "neutral" rating in a research note on Thursday, June 7th. Five analysts have rated the stock with a sell 
rating, six have given a hold rating and three have given a buy rating to the stock. Ryanair presently has an average 
rating of "Hold" and a consensus target price of $138.00. 
Ryanair stock  opened at $102.03 on Wednesday. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 52 week low of $94.50 and a 52 
week high of $127.61. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.72, a current ratio of 1.12 and a quick ratio of 
1.12. The stock has a market cap of $23.33 billion, a P/E ratio of 14.47 and a beta of 0.64.  
Fmr LLC Sells 1,167,280 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( RYAAY )
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last issued its quarterly earnings data on Monday, July 23rd. The transportation 
company reported $1.62 earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, topping analysts' consensus estimates of $1.55 
by $0.07. Ryanair had a return on equity of 29.19% and a net margin of 18.47%. The company had revenue of 
$2.48 billion during the quarter, compared to analysts' expectations of $2.41 billion.  sell-side analysts predict that  
Ryanair Holdings plc will post 6.28 EPS for the current year.  
Ryanair Company Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, continental Europe, Morocco, and Israel. It also offers various ancillary services, such as non-flight 
scheduled services and Internet-related services; and markets accommodation services and travel insurance 
through its Website, as well as engages in the in-flight sale of beverages, food, and merchandise.

PICTURE: Laudamotion to double fleet and introduce new livery Laudamotion is to double the size of its fleet 
next year, introduce a new livery, and offer staff ....
PICTURE: Laudamotion to double fleet and introduce new livery; 
Laudamotion is to double the size of its fleet next year, introduce a new 
livery, and offer staff improved pay as part of a growth strategy to be 
implemented following Ryanair's closing of its acquisition of a 75% stake in 
the Austrian regional carrier.
Flight International
August 29, 2018
Copyright 2018 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: FLIGHTGLOBAL.COM
Length: 223 words
Body
Laudamotion is to double the size of its fleet next year, introduce a new livery, and offer staff improved pay as part 
of a growth strategy to be implemented after Ryanair closed its acquisition of a 75% stake in the Austrian regional 
carrier.
Ryanair says the Vienna-based carrier's fleet will grow from nine Airbus A320s today to 18 next summer. A new 
livery which "reflects Laudamotion's Austrian heritage" will also be introduced, Ryanair adds.
Laudamotion
Staff are to receive pay rises and basic-pay guarantee". These include a basic starting wage for captains of 90,000 
($104,000), rising to a maximum of 180,000. First officers will get basic pay of 46,000, rising to a maximum of 
70,000, including flight pay.
A new five-days-on, three-days-off winter roster is to be introduced and staff will be relocated to new offices within 
Austria's capital. Christian Rolle has been appointed as the airline's personnel director and will take up his new role 
on 1 September.
Laudamotion chief executive Andreas Gruber states that the new A320s will allow the airline to boost passenger 
numbers 20% to five million in 2019 and welcomes the backing provided by the "enormous financial strength" of 
Ryanair.
The Irish carrier acquired just under 25% of Laudamotion earlier this year and in July gained regulatory approval to 
increase the stake to 75%.
PICTURE: Laudamotion to double fleet and introduce new livery Laudamotion is to double the size of its fleet 
next year, introduce a new livery, and offer staff ....
Load-Date: August 29, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair signs labour accord with Italian pilots Airlines
Ryanair signs labour accord with Italian pilots; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
August 29, 2018 Wednesday
Edition 1, USA Edition
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;BUSINESS; Pg. 12
Length: 359 words
Byline: JOSH SPERO
Body
Ryanair has signed a collective labour agreement with some of its Italian pilots, the first with any of its unions, after 
this summer's strikes.
Italy has the budget carrier's thirdlargest group of pilots, about 830, a fifth of the total - of whom about a third are 
represented by the Anpac union.
Ryanair said it welcomed the agreement and hoped it would be followed shortly by a deal with its Irish pilots.
"We have invited our UK, German and Spanish unions to meet with us in the coming days so that we can negotiate 
and hopefully agree similar pilot CLAs in these other larger markets," it said.
"These agreements demonstrate the real progress being made by Ryanair in its negotiations with its pilots and their 
unions across different EU markets."
One analyst said Ryanair was "playing divide and conquer quite well", given there are two other Italian pilot unions. 
It could also put pressure on other restive unions across Europe. It is a second piece of good news for the airline 
after its Irish pilots' union last week agreed to ballot its members on proposals regarding seniority, which determines 
pay, promotion and home bases. Irish pilots have staged five days of strikes this summer.
Kathryn Leonard, analyst at Numis, said progress was "clearly welcome" but until the details of the Italian and Irish 
agreements became public, it would be hard to tell what their long-term effects were on costs.
Ryanair signs labour accord with Italian pilots Airlines
Ryanair has been beset by pilot and cabin crew strikes this summer. On August 10, Irish, German, Belgian, 
Swedish and Dutch pilots took industrial action, forcing the airline to cancel 400 flights, or 15 per cent of its daily 
total.
The employees' demands have centred on improved pay and terms, including seniority, and (for non-Irish staff) the 
application of national, not Irish, law to govern contracts.
At a meeting in Frankfurt last week, unions from across Europe agreed to further strike action but did not announce 
a date.
The company decided to recognise some unions after more than 30 years when a scheduling crisis in September 
2017 forced it to cancel 2,000 flights. It had to pay (EURO)25m in compensation to passengers for the 
cancellations.
Load-Date: August 28, 2018
End of Document

Ryanair has signed a collective labour agreement with some of its Italian pilots, the first with any of its unions, after 
this summer's strikes.
Italy has the budget carrier's thirdlargest group of pilots, about 830, a fifth of the total - of whom about a third are 
represented by the Anpac union.

unions across different EU markets."
One analyst said Ryanair was "playing divide and conquer quite well", given there are two other Italian pilot unions. 
It could also put pressure on other restive unions across Europe. Ryanair's shares were up 2.6 per cent to 
(EURO)14.25 at the close yesterday.
It is a second piece of good news for the airline after its Irish pilots' union last week agreed to ballot its members on 
proposals regarding seniority, which determines pay, promotion and home bases. Irish pilots have staged five days 
of strikes this summer.
Ryanair signs pact with Italian pilots after summer of strikes Airlines
Kathryn Leonard, analyst at Numis, said progress was "clearly welcome" but until the details of the Italian and Irish 
agreements became public, it would be hard to tell what their long-term effects were on costs.
She added that "near-term earnings risk is abating".
Ryanair has been beset by pilot and cabin crew strikes this summer. On August 10, Irish, German, Belgian, 
Swedish and Dutch pilots took industrial action, forcing the airline to cancel 400 flights, or 15 per cent of its daily 
total.
Its Italian pilots have not gone on strike but Italian cabin crew have.
The employees' demands have centred on improved pay and terms, including seniority, and (for non-Irish staff) the 
application of national, not Irish, law to govern contracts.

a date.

2017 forced it to cancel 2,000 flights. It had to pay (EURO)25m in compensation to passengers for the 
cancellations.

European ADRs Move Higher in Tuesday Trading
European ADRs Move Higher in Tuesday Trading
MT Newswires Live Briefs
August 28, 2018 Tuesday 10:47 AM EST
Copyright 2018 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 250 words
Body
 American depositary receipts of European stocks were trading 0.07% higher at 137.52 on the Bank of New York 
Mellon Europe ADR Index on Tuesday.
In continental Europe, the gainers were led by biotech company Zealand Pharma (ZEAL), and pharmaceutical firm 
Oasmia Pharmaceutical (OASM), which rose 3.7% and 2.6% respectively. They were followed by 
biopharmaceutical company argenx (ARGX), and kidney dialysis company Fresenius Medical Care (FMS), which 
were up 2.5% and 1.7%.
The decliners in continental Europe were led by internet browser company Opera (OPRA), and telecommunications 
provider Telecom Italia (TI), which fell 5.7% and 1.6% respectively. They were followed by Deutsche Bank (DB), 
and ASML (ASML), a manufacturer of chip-making equipment, which were off 1.3% and 1.2%.
In the UK and Ireland, the gainers were led by gene therapy company gene therapy company Nightstar (NITE), and 
airline operator Ryanair (RYAAY), which were up 2.8% and 2.1% respectively. They were followed by mining 
company BHP Billiton (BBL), and biopharmaceutical firm Akari Therapeutics (AKTX), which rose 1.6% and 1.1%.
The decliners in the UK and Ireland were led by biopharmaceutical company Midatech Pharma (MTP), and 
construction materials supplier CRH (CRH), which lost 3.5% and 1.8% respectively. They were followed by 
consumer goods company British American Tobacco (BTI), and biopharmaceutical company GW Pharmaceuticals 
(GWPH), which were down 1.7% and 0.5%.
Price: 14.91, Change: +0.50, Percent Change: +3.47
Load-Date: August 29, 2018

Italian pilots union votes to approve Ryanair deal
Italian pilots union votes to approve Ryanair deal
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 28, 2018 Tuesday 6:31 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 242 words
Byline: Lena Klimkeit in Rome and Silvia Kusidlo in London
Dateline: Rome (dpa) - 
Body
The Italian pilots union ANPAC has voted to approve a collective labour agreement reached with low-cost airline 
Ryanair following a protracted a labour dispute, both sides have announced.
The more than 300 members of Italy's largest airline pilots union approved the agreement by a large majority on 
Monday evening, the union said on Tuesday.
ANPAC called the deal an "historic event," and "the first collective agreement signed by Ryanair in Europe."
Italy is one of the Irish airline's largest markets.
The agreement, reached after eight months of negotiations and signed in Italy, ensures better protection and pay 
conditions for pilots, the union said.
Ryanair said it hopes to sign a similar deal with its Irish pilots in the near future. The airline reached an agreement 
with Irish pilots' union Forsa this week, but the pilots still have to vote to approve the deal.
Strikes by Ryanair pilots across Europe have resulted in the cancellation of hundreds of flights during the past two 
months.
Portugal, Spain, Belgium, Germany, Sweden and the Netherlands are among the other countries that have 
mounted strike actions.
Ryanair only started recognizing pilots unions last year, taking the step during negotiations to ward off a previous 
threat of strikes.
Italian pilots union votes to approve Ryanair deal
The company said on Tuesday that it has invited unions in Britain, Germany and Spain to negotiate in the coming 
days.

reports. Five investment analysts have rated the stock with a sell recommendation, six have assigned  a hold 
recommendation and three have issued  a buy recommendation on  the company.

Tuesday, August 7th. Finally, ValuEngine  cut Ryanair from a "hold" rating to a "sell" rating in a report on Tuesday, 
July 24th.

company. UBS Group AG lifted its stake in  Ryanair by 40.1% during the 1st quarter. UBS Group AG now owns

the last quarter.  Finally, FIL Ltd lifted its stake in  Ryanair by 659.3% during the 1st quarter. FIL Ltd now owns

earnings ratio of 14.14 and a beta of 0.64. Ryanair has a 52-week low of $94.50 and a 52-week high of $127.61.

reported $1.62 earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, beating the Thomson Reuters' consensus estimate of

Ryanair Company Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, continental Europe, Morocco, and Israel. It also offers various ancillary services, such as non-flight 
scheduled services and Internet-related services; and markets accommodation services and travel insurance 
through its Website, as well as engages in the in-flight sale of beverages, food, and merchandise.

Italian pilots union votes to approve Ryanair deal
Italian pilots union votes to approve Ryanair deal
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
August 28, 2018 Tuesday 6:32 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 238 words
Body
       ROME (dpa-AFX) - The Italian pilots union ANPAC has voted to approve a collective labour agreement 
reached with low-cost airline Ryanair following a protracted a labour dispute, both sides have announced.  The 
more than 300 members of Italy's largest airline pilots union approved the agreement by a large majority on 
Monday evening, the union said on Tuesday. 
 ANPAC called the deal an 'historic event,' and 'the first collective agreement signed by Ryanair in Europe.'  Italy is 
one of the Irish airline's largest markets.  The agreement, reached after eight months of negotiations and signed in 
Italy, ensures better protection and pay conditions for pilots, the union said.  Ryanair said it hopes to sign a similar 
deal with its Irish pilots in the near future. The airline reached an agreement with Irish pilots' union Forsa this week, 
but the pilots still have to vote to approve the deal.  Strikes by Ryanair pilots across Europe have resulted in the 
cancellation of hundreds of flights during the past two months.  Portugal, Spain, Belgium, Germany, Sweden and 
the Netherlands are among the other countries that have mounted strike actions.  Ryanair only started recognizing 
pilots unions last year, taking the step during negotiations to ward off a previous threat of strikes.  The company 
said on Tuesday that it has invited unions in Britain, Germany and Spain to negotiate in the coming days.   
Copyright dpa    
Load-Date: August 28, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair 's Italian Pilots Approve Collective Labor Agreement
Ryanair's Italian Pilots Approve Collective Labor Agreement
MT Newswires Live Briefs
August 28, 2018 Tuesday 8:57 AM EST
Copyright 2018 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 79 words
Body
 Ryanair (RYAAY) said Tuesday that its Italian pilots had voted to approve a new collective labor agreement, which 
was negotiated and signed between the Irish budget carrier and the Italian Airline Pilots Association on Aug. 9.
The vote comes after the FORSA trade union has signed and recommended a mediation agreement to the airliner's 
Irish pilots. The pilots had voted overwhelmingly to approve the agreement, Ryanair said.

Length: 77 words
Body
 US-based value investment fund Harris Associates has acquired a 3.07% stake in Ryanair (RYAAY), the Irish 
budget airliner said in a filing Tuesday.
The company also said that the investment management company crossed the 3% reporting threshold on Aug. 24.
The move is seen by industry analysts as a sign of support for the struggling low-budget carrier, which has been 
working to resolve disputes with Irish pilots.

Ryanair's Italian Pilots Vote In Favor Of CLA For Italy
Ryanair's Italian Pilots Vote In Favor Of CLA For Italy
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
August 28, 2018 Tuesday 12:32 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 102 words
Body
       DUBLIN (dpa-AFX) - Irish low-cost airline Ryanair (RYA.L, RYAAY) on Tuesday confirmed that its Italian pilots 
had voted overwhelmingly in favor of a new Collective Labor Agreement (CLA) which was negotiated and signed 
between Ryanair and ANPAC (Italian Airline Pilots Association) on August 9 last. Italy accounts for 20 percent of 
ryanair's fleet and pilots.  This is the first pilot CLA in one of its largest EU markets. The vote in Italy comes shortly 
after Irish union FORSA signed, and recommended, a mediation agreement to Ryanair's Irish pilots, who are 
currently voting to approve this agreement.

of the stock is owned by institutional investors and hedge funds.

of 0.64. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 1 year low of $94.50 and a 1 year high of $127.61. The company has a quick 
ratio of 1.12, a current ratio of 1.12 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.72.

Ryanair 's orry' for unsigned cheques TRAVEL
Ryanair 'sorry' for unsigned cheques; TRAVEL
Financial Times (London, England)
August 25, 2018 Saturday
Edition 1, Asian Edition
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: MONEY;BUSINESS; Pg. 2
Length: 76 words
Body
Low-cost carrier Ryanair has left some customers owed compensation shortchanged after it sent them unsigned 
cheques they were unable to cash.
Ryanair said that an "admin error" had resulted in a "tiny number of cheques" - less than 190 out of over 20,000 
compensation cheques in July - being posted without a required signatory.
The airline said the affected cheques had been reissued last week and apologised to customers for the 
inconvenience caused. Josh Spero
Load-Date: August 25, 2018
End of Document

purchased a new position in shares of  Ryanair in the first quarter worth about $254,000.  Oppenheimer Asset

of $127.61. The stock has a market cap of $23.18 billion, a price-to-earnings ratio of 13.92 and a beta of 0.64. The 
company has a quick ratio of 1.12, a current ratio of 1.12 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.72.

company reported $0.30 earnings per share for the quarter, beating analysts' consensus estimates of $0.25 by 
$0.05. Ryanair had a net margin of 18.47% and a return on equity of 29.19%. The business had revenue of $1.62 
billion during the quarter, compared to analysts' expectations of $1.56 billion.  equities research analysts predict 
that  Ryanair Holdings plc will post 6.28 earnings per share for the current fiscal year.

rating to a "strong-buy" rating in a research note on Friday, May 25th. UBS Group  reaffirmed a "buy" rating on

from an "outperform" rating to a "neutral" rating in a research note on Thursday, June 7th. ValuEngine  downgraded 
shares of Ryanair from a "buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a research note on Wednesday, May 9th. Finally, Exane 
BNP Paribas downgraded shares of Ryanair from an "outperform" rating to a "neutral" rating in a research note on 
Thursday, June 7th. Five research analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, six have assigned  a hold rating 
American Century Companies Inc. Decreases Stake in Ryanair Holdings plc ( RYAAY )
and three have issued  a buy rating to the company. The company  has a consensus rating of "Hold" and an 
average price target of $138.00. 
About Ryanair
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, continental Europe, Morocco, and Israel. It also offers various ancillary services, such as non-flight 
scheduled services and Internet-related services; and markets accommodation services and travel insurance 
through its Website, as well as engages in the in-flight sale of beverages, food, and merchandise.

Prince Charles Won't Need This Travel Item Anymore When He Becomes King
Prince Charles Won't Need This Travel Item Anymore When He Becomes 
King
International Business Times News
August 24, 2018 Friday 9:50 AM EST
Copyright 2018 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 440 words
Body
Aug 24, 2018( International Business Times News: http://www.ibtimes.com Delivered by Newstex)  Prince Charles 
no longer has to travel with his passport when he becomes king. In the United Kingdom, passports are issued in the 
name of the monarch. 
This means that they are currently given by Queen Elizabeth II. Since she is the head of the state, the Queen 
doesn't travel with her passport. 'Her Britannic Majesty's Secretary of State requests and requires in the name of 
Her Majesty all those whom it may concern to allow the bearer to pass freely without let or hindrance and to afford 
the bearer such assistance and protection as may be necessary,' the statement on the British passport read. When 
Prince Charles takes over the throne, he will no longer need to travel with the document. However, Prince Charles' 
wife, Camilla Parker Bowles, still cannot travel without her passport. Kara Godfrey, a journalist for Express[1], said 
that even though Prince Charles no longer needs his passport when traveling, he might still be asked some 
questions whenever he flies in and out of the country. These can include questions about his age and address for 
security purposes. In related news, Prince Charles is known as one of the royals that go all out during his trips. It 
was revealed that he spent over $1.5 million[2] on his travels last year. He also travels via his private jet. His most 
expensive tour was of India, Malaysia, Brunei, and Singapore. Prince Charles' sons, Prince William and Prince 
Harry are not like him because the siblings get to travel on commercial flights. In fact, Prince Harry has also 
traveled with Meghan Markle[3] on a commercial flight. In 2015, Prince William flew by Ryanair to Scotland, and an 
eyewitness said that it was refreshing to see a member of the royal family taking a cheap flight. Prince William was 
joined by his bodyguard at that time. In 2011, he also traveled on economy class with Kate Middleton. Prince 
Charles no longer needs a passport when traveling to other countries when he becomes king. Pictured: Prince 
Charles visits 617 Squadron, the UK's first F-35 Lightning Squadron based at RAF Marham, Kings Lynn on July 27, 
2018 
in 
Norfolk, 
England. 
Photo: 
Getty 
Images/Chris 
Radburn 
- 
WPA 
Pool

69p-royal-expenditure [ 3]:            https://www.express.co.uk/news/royal/999582/meghan-markle-prince-harry-

the hole left by the delayed listing of state energy group Saudi Aramco.

proposals to reform the industry and halt a review by the competition regulator.

an end to the summer of strikes.

Hammond launched a new attack on Tory colleagues by warning that it would significantly damage the 
economy.

country’s retail banking sector with a market leading rate for savers.

end of June, but profits failed to keep pace, squeezing margins.
•

stake in the Intercity Express Programme and cashed in on investments overseas.
•
The Times: The explorer and producer Premier Oil said that higher oil prices led to operating profits rising 
to $185.5 million in the first half from $141.4 million the year before.
•
The Daily Telegraph: Tarmac owner CRH has unveiled a hike in interim profits and a fattened dividend 
despite having suffered amid the cold weather earlier in the year, signalling growing confidence in 
construction markets in both the US and Europe.

half interim pre-tax profits of £91.8 million, up 17%, and lifted the interim dividend by 23% to 4.3p.
•
Financial Times: Australian airline Qantas has announced 14% rise in pre-tax profits to $1.2 billion as its 
domestic flourished.
•
Daily Mail: BrewDog saw its sales rise by 55% to £78 million in the first half of this year, with UK sales 
surging by 83%, as the Scottish-based group moves ahead with its expansion plans.
•
The Times: Fulham Shore, the Aim-quoted company that operates 16 Real Greek and 42 Franco Manca 
restaurants, has reported a rise in revenues for both chains in the first 21 weeks of its financial year.
•
Financial Times: Tata Steel’s UK arm suffered annual pre-tax losses of £222 million last year because of 
higher raw materials prices, operational issues and the increased costs of carbon emissions.
•
The Times: Ark Invest, one of Tesla’s institutional shareholders, has warned that Elon Musk would “deprive 
a broad and loyal investor base of one of the most important investment opportunities of their lifetimes” if 
he takes the company private.
•
The Daily Telegraph: The gambling regulator has fined National Lottery operator Camelot £1.2 million for a 
series of failings.
•
The Times: The European Central Bank has warned that protectionism and trade wars pose the greatest 
risk to plans to end quantitative easing in the eurozone by the end of this year.

Head-To-Head Survey: Southwest Airlines ( LUV ) and Ryanair ( RYAAY )
Head-To-Head Survey: Southwest Airlines (LUV) and Ryanair (RYAAY)
DailyPolitical
August 24, 2018 Friday 9:11 AM EST
Copyright 2018 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 763 words
Body
Aug 24, 2018( DailyPolitical: http://www.dailypolitical.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  Southwest Airlines (NASDAQ: 
RYAAY[1]) and Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY[2]) are both large-cap transportation companies, but which is the 
superior investment? We will compare the two companies based on the strength of their risk, analyst 
recommendations, valuation, profitability, dividends, institutional ownership and earnings. ProfitabilityThis table 
compares Southwest Airlines and Ryanair's net margins, return on equity and return on assets. 
Insider ...stitutional Ownership77.2% of Southwest Airlines shares are owned by institutional investors. 
Comparatively, 44.2% of Ryanair shares are owned by institutional investors. 0.2% of Southwest Airlines shares are 
owned by insiders. Strong institutional ownership is an indication that large money managers, endowments and 
hedge funds believe a stock is poised for long-term growth.Volatility and Risk Southwest Airlines has a beta of 1.15, 
suggesting that its share price is 15% more volatile than the S...00. Comparatively, Ryanair has a beta of 0.64, 
suggesting that its share price is 36% less volatile than the S...00. Analyst RecommendationsThis is a breakdown 
of recent recommendations for Southwest Airlines and Ryanair, as provided by MarketBeat.  Southwest Airlines 
currently has a consensus price target of $67.11, indicating a potential upside of 10.00%. Given Southwest Airlines' 
stronger consensus rating and higher probable upside, equities analysts plainly believe Southwest Airlines is more 
favorable than Ryanair. Valuation and Earnings This table compares Southwest Airlines and Ryanair's top-line 
revenue, earnings per share (EPS) and valuation. Southwest Airlines has higher revenue and earnings than 
Ryanair. Ryanair is trading at a lower price-to-earnings ratio than Southwest Airlines, indicating that it is currently 
the more affordable of the two stocks. DividendsSouthwest Airlines pays an annual dividend of $0.64 per share and 
has a dividend yield of 1.0%. Ryanair does not pay a dividend. Southwest Airlines pays out 18.3% of its earnings in 
the form of a dividend. Southwest Airlines has increased its dividend for 6 consecutive years. SummarySouthwest 
Airlines beats Ryanair on 11 of the 17 factors compared between the two stocks.About Southwest 
AirlinesSouthwest Airlines Co. operates a passenger airline that provides scheduled air transportation services in 
the United States and near-international markets. As of December 31, 2017, the company operated a total of 706 
Boeing 737 aircraft; and served 100 destinations in 40 states, the District of Columbia, and the Commonwealth of 
Puerto Rico, as well as 10 near-international countries, including Mexico, Jamaica, the Bahamas, Aruba, the 
Dominican Republic, Costa Rica, Belize, Cuba, the Cayman Islands, and Turks and Caicos. It also sells frequent 
flyer points and related services to business partners participating in the Rapid Rewards frequent flyer program, 
such as car rental agencies, hotels, restaurants, and retailers. In addition, the company offers a suite of digital 
platforms to support customers' needs across the travel journey, including Southwest.com, mobile.southwest.com, 
an iOS app, an android app, an email subscription service, and push notifications; and Swabiz.com, a Website for 
business customers that offer businesses shared stored company credit cards, company activity reporting, and 
Head-To-Head Survey: Southwest Airlines ( LUV ) and Ryanair ( RYAAY )
centralized traveler management services. Southwest Airlines Co. was founded in 1967 and is based in Dallas, 
Texas.About RyanairRyanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline 
services in Ireland, the United Kingdom, continental Europe, Morocco, and Israel. It also offers various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; and markets accommodation services 
and travel insurance through its Website, as well as engages in the in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise. In addition, the company sells bus and rail tickets onboard its aircraft and through its Website; and 
markets car parking, attractions, and activities, as well as gift vouchers through its Website. It operates a fleet of 
350 Boeing 737-800 aircraft and 33 leased aircraft; and offers approximately 2,000 scheduled short-haul flights per 
day serving approximately 200 airports primarily in Europe. The company was founded in 1985 and is 
headquartered in Swords, Ireland. [ 1]: https://www.marketbeat.com/stocks/NYSE/LUV/ [ 2]:            
https://www.marketbeat.com/stocks/NYSE/LUV/

Ryanair hopes for end to strikes after reaching deal with Irish pilots' union
Ryanair hopes for end to strikes after reaching deal with Irish pilots' union
Financial Times (London, England)
August 24, 2018 Friday
Edition 1, Asian Edition
Copyright 2018 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: COMPANIES AND MARKETS;BUSINESS; Pg. 13
Length: 327 words
Byline: JOSH SPERO
Body
Ryanair and its Irish pilots' union have announced an agreement on their labour contract, potentially bringing to an 
end a summer of strikes.
After several days of mediation, Forsa trade union said it would recommend that its members accept the agreement 
when it goes to a ballot.
Ryanair said it would take the proposals to its board "in due course after the Irish-based pilots have voted on this 
signed agreement".
The company's shares closed 5.9 per cent higher at (EURO)13.92 yesterday.
In an email to its members seen by the Financial Times, the union said it had reached a tentative agreement on two 
issues regarding "seniority" - which determines a pilot's pay, promotion and home bases - while it was still in 
discussions on annual leave.
Joost van Doesburg of the Dutch VNV pilots' union, which has also gone on strike this summer, said: "We still have 
some questions, because is it a national Irish seniority list - that would be in our opinion quite useless - or will this 
be a master seniority list for all Ryanair pilots in Europe? Then it would be a very positive intermediate step."
Ryanair hopes for end to strikes after reaching deal with Irish pilots' union
Forsa's members, who account for about a third of Ryanair's Irish pilots, have gone on strike five times this 
summer, most recently on August 10, when they were joined by pilots from Germany, Belgium, Sweden and the 
Netherlands. The airline was forced to cancel 400 flights, or 15 per cent of its daily total.
Ryanair pilots' unions met in Frankfurt on Monday to discuss further strike action, with one person at the meeting 
saying a new strike had been agreed, with a date to be confirmed.
The person said: "The countries that were in the meeting ... are still in strike mode instead of negotiation mode."
The person added that the Irish agreement might give Ryanair more time to concentrate on its disputes with other 
unions, which want to discuss pay increases and the use of national, rather than Irish, law for employment 
contracts. Neither was an issue for Irish pilots.
Load-Date: August 23, 2018
End of Document

European ADRs Move Lower in Thursday Trading
European ADRs Move Lower in Thursday Trading
MT Newswires Live Briefs
August 23, 2018 Thursday 11:29 AM EST
Copyright 2018 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 231 words
Body
 American depositary receipts of European stocks were trading 0.17% lower at 135.63 on the Bank of New York 
Mellon Europe ADR Index on Thursday.
In continental Europe, the gainers were led by pharmaceutical firm Oasmia Pharmaceutical (OASM), and 
biopharmaceutical company DBV Technologies (DBVT), which rose 4.4% and 3% respectively. They were followed 
by biotech company Zealand Pharma (ZEAL), and automation company ABB (ABB), which were up 2.5% and 
2.2%. 
The decliners in continental Europe were led by geophysical equipment company CGG (CGG), and 
telecommunications provider Telecom Italia (TI), which fell 4.4% and 2.4% respectively. They were followed by 
Deutsche Bank (DB), and marketing firm Criteo (CRTO), which were off 1.9% and 1.8%.
In the UK and Ireland, the gainers were led by airplane lessor Fly Leasing (FLY), and airline operator Ryanair 
(RYAAY), which climbed 6.6% and 4.9% respectively. They were followed by biotech firm Autolus Therapeutics 
(AUTL), and biopharmaceutical company Adaptimmune Therapeutics (ADAP), which rose 3.7% each.
The decliners in the UK and Ireland were led by biopharmaceutical firm Amarin (AMRN), and consumer goods 
company British American Tobacco (BTI), which fell 3.3% and 1.4% respectively. They were followed by mining 
company Rio Tinto (RIO), and bank HSBC (HSBC), which were off 1.2% each.
Price: 14.83, Change: +0.95, Percent Change: +6.84
Load-Date: August 24, 2018
End of Document
LONDON MARKET CLOSE: Miners Sink FTSE As US -China Trade Spat Escalates
LONDON MARKET CLOSE: Miners Sink FTSE As US-China Trade Spat 
Escalates
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
August 23, 2018 Thursday 12:04 PM EST
Copyright 2018 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 1436 words
Body
 Stocks in London ended mixed on Thursday, as a fall in heavyweight mining stocks impeded gains in the FTSE 
100, as the US and China's tit-for-tat trade war intensified.
The FTSE 100 index closed down 0.2%, or 11.02 points at 7,563.22. The FTSE 250 ended up 0.1%, or 22.97 
points, at 20,665.47, and the AIM All-Share closed up 0.1%, or 7.75 points, at 1,092.55.
The Cboe UK 100 closed down 0.2% at 12,818.30, the Cboe UK 250 closed up 0.2% at 18,771.98, and the Cboe 
UK Small Companies closed down 0.1% at 12,330.33.
"Despite briefly spiking above 7,600, the FTSE 100 was unable to retain its strength and moved into negative 
territory towards the end of the session. An escalation of trade tensions between the US and China hit metal prices 
pulling miners lower," said City Index analyst Fiona Cincotta.
China retaliated in the same measure against the US government's decision to impose 25% import duty on 
additional Chinese products worth USD16 billion, escalating a trade war between the two economic powerhouses.
The US has applied new tariffs to a vast range of goods in 279 product categories, including children's cots and 
bedding, animal medicines, semiconductors, plastics, chemicals and railway equipment, shrimps and shrimp 
products, handbags and fridges.
China responded immediately with tariffs on 333 US products worth USD16 billion. They include coal, copper scrap, 
fuel, buses, cars, medical equipment, Harley motorcycles, bourbon and orange juice.
US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross tried to downplay the counter-effects in an interview on CNBC.
"Naturally they'll retaliate a little bit. But at the end of the day, we have many more bullets than they do. They know 
it," Ross said.
LONDON MARKET CLOSE: Miners Sink FTSE As US -China Trade Spat Escalates
On the London Stock Exchange, miners were weighing on the large cap index with Anglo American, down 2.7%, 
Antofagasta, down 1.0% and Rio Tinto down 1.0%. 
Imperial Brands and Carnival closed down 1.8% and 1.1% respectively after the stocks went ex-dividend meaning 
new buyers no longer qualify for the latest dividend payout. 
In the FTSE 250, TalkTalk Telecom Group ended as the best performer, up 8.4% after Barclays upgraded the home 
phone and broadband provider to Overweight from Equal Weight saying its operating trends are set to improve 
following years of losing market share. 
Elsewhere, Ryanair Holdings closed up 5.5% after the Irish carrier reached an agreement with its Irish pilot union in 
a labour dispute, both sides have announced.
"Following a 22-hour negotiating session, which began on Wednesday morning and concluded Thursday morning, 
agreement has been reached between Forsa and Ryanair in the pilots' dispute," the pilots' trade union Forsa said.
The pilots now have to vote to approve the deal, with the union recommending that they accept it. In the dispute 
over holiday time, transfers and promotions, 100 of Ryanair's 350 Irish-based pilots took part in five days of strike 
action.
Elsewhere, the Saudi government remains committed to an initial public offering of the state oil giant Aramco, but at 
a "time of its own choosing," Energy Minister Khalid Al Falih said. His remarks come in response to speculation that 
Saudi authorities called off plans to list the company on the stock exchange, expected to be one of the biggest in 
history. 
The Aramco listing is thought to be part of an ambitious economic reform plan, known as Vision 2030, launched by 
Saudi Arabia's powerful Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman to diversify the kingdom's oil-reliant economy. 
"The government remains committed to the IPO of Saudi Aramco at a time of its own choosing when conditions are 
optimal," Aramco chairman Al Falih said in a statement, according to the official Saudi news agency SPA. 
The pound was lower against the dollar quoted at USD1.2830 at the London equities close, compared to 
USD1.2906 at close Wednesday. Sterling hit an intraday high of USD1.2917 in afternoon trade before giving back 
gains. 
In domestic political news, Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab reiterated the UK government's conviction that it can and 
will agree a deal with the EU.
Raab told reporters that plans were being made to recruit an extra 9,000 staff into the civil service to deal with 
Brexit, in addition to 7,000 currently working on preparations.
A further 1,000 more Border Force staff are to be recruited, more than triple the additional 300 previously planned 
for. Raab dismissed "misinformation" about what may happen in the event no deal is reached by March, saying his 
stress levels were "fine".
The government published 24 technical papers setting out preparations and scenarios that could play out if a Brexit 
deal cannot be agreed before Britain leaves the EU in March.
The key points from the first set of papers cover several aspects of British life and trade including the removal of an 
EU ban on credit and debit card surcharges. UK citizens living in Europe facing the possibility of losing access to 
their pensions and consumers facing a potential cost increase for shopping online.
"The game of poker between the UK and EU goes on, but it is clear that the UK's journey after a 'no deal' will be 
much harder than the EU's. With this in mind, the pound was a little jittery, but the references to 'progress' in Raab's 
speech helped to calm the currency for a brief period before the US economic strength-related selling resumed," 
said IG chief market analyst Chris Beauchamp.
LONDON MARKET CLOSE: Miners Sink FTSE As US -China Trade Spat Escalates
On the economic front, UK retailers reported an above-average sales growth in the year to August but the outlook 
was less positive with declines in employment, investment intention and business optimism, a closely watched 
survey showed Thursday.
A net balance of 29% said their sales volumes increased in August, according to the latest quarterly Distributive 
Trades Survey from the Confederation of British Industry. However, the balance for the next month fell to 22%.
Further, a net 8% of retailers expected their overall business situation to deteriorate slightly over the next three 
months.
In Paris the CAC 40 ended flat while the DAX 30 in Frankfurt ended down 0.1%. 
The euro was a touch lower against the dollar at USD1.1569 at the European equities close, against USD1.1599 
late Wednesday. 
In economic news from the continent, the euro area private sector continued to expand in August, albeit with the 
rate of expansion remaining one of the weakest seen over the past 18 months, flash data from IHS Markit showed.
The composite output index rose marginally to 54.4 in August from 54.3 in July. But the score was slightly below the 
forecast of 54.5.
The services Purchasing Managers' Index also came in at 54.4, up from 54.2 a month ago. The score came in line 
with expectations.
Meanwhile, the manufacturing PMI fell unexpectedly to a 21-month low of 54.6 from 55.1 in July. The reading was 
expected to rise slightly to 55.2.
Within the eurozone, growth accelerated in France and Germany but slowed across the rest of the single-currency 
area.
Stocks in New York were lower at the London equities close. The DJIA was down 0.4%, the S&P 500 index down 
0.2% and the Nasdaq Composite down 0.1%.
Meanwhile, US President Donald Trump dodged a question in an interviewed broadcast Thursday about pardoning 
his one-time campaign manager Paul Manafort, who was convicted this week on federal tax and bank fraud 
charges.
Without saying whether he is weighing a pardon, Trump minimized the charges against Manafort, 69, who faces 
decades in prison.
"I have great respect for what he's done in terms of what he's gone through," Trump told Fox News, a cable channel 
that he frequently praises.
"I would say what he did, some of the charges they threw against him, every consultant, every lobbyist in 
Washington probably does."
Brent oil was firm quoted at USD74.56 a barrel at the London equities close from USD74.26 at the close 
Wednesday. 
Gold was lower quoted at USD1,189.30 an ounce at the London equities close against USD1,195.95 late 
Wednesday.
The UK corporate calendar on Friday has half year results from IT services provider Computacenter, construction 
and property development company Henry Boot and agriculture and engineering firm Camellia. 
The economic events calendar on Friday has inflation data from Japan at 0030 BST, Germany GDP readings at 
0700 BST, UK mortgage approval figures at 0930 BST and US durable goods data at 1330 BST.

In addition, Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City-sponsored Jackson Hole Symposium continues on Friday on the 
topic of "Changing Market Structure and Implications for Monetary Policy". US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome 
Powell is set to make his maiden address to the Wyoming gathering of central bankers at 1500 BST.

Ryanair reaches agreement with Irish union in pilots dispute
Ryanair reaches agreement with Irish union in pilots dispute
Business World (Digest)
August 23, 2018 Thursday
Copyright 2018 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: IRELAND
Length: 328 words
Byline: Business World
Body
Ryanair reached an agreement with the trade union representing its Irish pilots on Thursday, a breakthrough that 
sent its shares sharply higher as the budget airline strives to quell staff protests around Europe.
Ryanair passengers have suffered hundreds of flight cancellations this summer because of protests by pilots over 
slow progress in negotiating collective labor agreements, hurting average fares at Europe's largest low-cost carrier.
The Irish airline endured its worst one-day strike earlier in August after a walk-out by pilots in five European 
countries disrupted the plans of an estimated 55,000 people at the height of the summer holiday season.
That included a fifth 24-hour walkout of the summer by around a quarter of its pilots in Ireland that prompted 
Ryanair to propose fresh talks with the help of a mediator that began last week and ended early on Thursday after a 
22-hour session.
"The proposed agreement will now go to ballot, with a recommendation for acceptance from Forsa and its Ryanair 
pilot representatives," pilots' union Forsa said in a statement on Thursday, adding the talks' mediator asked that 
neither side makes further comment while the ballot is conducted.
Ryanair said it would take the proposals to its board after the Irish-based pilots had voted on the agreement.
Some of the other trade unions stuck in negotiations around Europe have said they are watching the Irish talks 
closely.
Ryanair employs more than 4,000 pilots, with around 350 of them based in Ireland. Negotiations in the country have 
been among the most difficult, the company has said.
Ryanair reaches agreement with Irish union in pilots dispute
Shares in Ryanair were 5.4% higher at 13.855 euros at 0815 GMT, top of the regional STOXX 600 benchmark 
index.
The stock is still down 16% since the strike action ramped up in mid-July and remains below the 14.21 euros it 
slumped to in December when Ryanair shocked markets by agreeing to recognize unions for the first time in its 30-
year history. (Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie
